A data type that stores a signed, exact numeric value described as the number of digits appearing before and after the decimal point, with a maximum of 29 total digits. All possible digits cannot be represented if you are using the maximum number of digits.
The process of rewriting parts of a file to contiguous sectors on a hard disk to increase the speed of access and retrieval.
The blank area between two or more columns of text or between two facing pages in a publication.
In a 2-D chart, the area bounded by the axes, including all data series. In a 3-D chart, the area bounded by the axes, including the data series, category names, tick-mark labels, and axis titles.

A small piece of code that can be transported over the Internet and executed on the recipient's machine. The term is especially used to refer to such programs as they are embedded in line as objects in HTML documents on the World Wide Web.
The alternate calendar that is selected from within Outlook. The secondary calendar appears when dual calendar support is enabled.
The condition of a field, record, recordset, or database that makes it read-only to all users except the user currently modifying it.
Audio, video, images, text, or any other information that is contained in a digital media file or stream.

The basic element that holds information in Outlook (similar to a file in other programs). Items include e-mail messages, appointments, contacts, tasks, journal entries, notes, posted items, and documents.

The basic element that holds information in Outlook (similar to a file in other programs). Items include e-mail messages, appointments, contacts, tasks, journal entries, notes, posted items, and documents.
In a mail-merge operation, the document that contains the text and graphics that are the same for each version of the merged document, for example, the return address or salutation in a form letter.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
The structure or organization of data in a file.
An organization with more than 1000 employees and more than 500 personal computers.
Text that does not display in the normal view of a document's content.
A feature that allows users to see and interact with E-mail messages and their attachments side by side in the reading pane.

A font display technology that dramatically improves font display resolution so that letters on the computer screen appear smooth, not jagged. ClearType dramatically improves the readability of text on color LCD monitors with a digital interface, such as those found in laptops and high-quality flat-panel desktop displays.
A space that is used to prevent multiple words from breaking if they fall at the end of a line.

A fundamental data type that holds double-precision floating-point numbers. It's stored as a 64-bit number ranging in value from approximately -1.797E308 to -4.940E-324 (negative), from 4.94E-324 to 1.797E308 (positive), and 0.

A precompiled collection of SQL statements and optional control-of-flow statements stored under a name and processed as a unit. They are stored in an SQL database and can be run with one call from an application.

A worksheet view that displays the areas to be printed and the locations of page breaks. The area to be printed is displayed in white, automatic page breaks appear as dashed lines, and manual page breaks appear as solid lines.
A set of software functionality designed to solve a specific problem or to provide a new functionality to the user.
Files that are used to help detect harmful or unwanted software and to prevent it from installing or running on your computer.

A button on the message toolbar that compares the names in the To, Cc, and Bcc boxes against the names in the Address Book and against those contact folders that you've specified as Outlook Address Books.

A user interface element that provides users with a quick and easy way to navigate across a large group of opened Web pages by providing the user with a visual representation of all of the opened thumbnails. Through this visualization, the user can easily spot and select a desired thumbnail.
A "container" for a set of separate files (or subdocuments). You can use a master document to set up and manage a multipart document, such as a book with several chapters.
The speed at which binary digits are transmitted.
To change a program in order to be able to run it on a different computer.
A feature that allows you to set up your computer so that when you insert a CD or DVD, it will play automatically and you won't have to select your preferences every time.
A list in which each item or block of text is preceded by a number.

A document area that contains a range of text distinct from other areas of text in a document. For example, if a document includes body text, footnotes, and headers, it contains a main text story, footnotes story, and headers story.
Personal configurations of a program or operating system.
A text file containing code to apply semantics such as page layout specifications to published content.
A vertical area along the left edge of the document window that displays the name of the paragraph style that is applied to each paragraph.
A serial communications port used to connect a device, such as a modem, printer, or mobile device, to a computer.
The formal name for Excel 12 file format. The Excel XML Format has an open, royalty-free specification, and is the technology licensed to external parties.
A database object that stores data in records (rows) and fields (columns). The data is usually about a particular category of things, such as employees or orders.
A type of CD on which files can be copied, erased, and replaced.
A legal agreement between Microsoft and the user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of software.
For local area networks (LANs), a device that is connected to the network and is capable of communicating with other network devices.
Used by Microsoft Exchange to identify, locate, and open a form.
A function of some Web browsers that allows users to surf and view multiple pages by loading Web sites into sections (or tabs) of one page, rather than multiple pages.
A notification bar warning the user about data that is blocked in the loaded file. Trust Bars can be for information only (non-actionable) or actionable.
Of or pertaining to documents, data, software, or hardware that existed prior to a certain time.
A rectangular array of pixels applied to a visual object.
In Task Manager, the current working set of a process, in kilobytes. The current working set is the number of pages currently resident in memory.
Any ink that you add to a file that is not recognized as handwriting.
The structure or appearance of a unit of data, such as a field, or text in a message body.
A natural number, zero, or the negative of a natural number.
To transfer a copy of a file from a local computer to a remote computer by means of a modem or network.
A character that is not found on your keyboard and must be inserted from within the software or by pressing a combination of keys on your keyboard.
For a computer system, to be in an inactive state, but not shut off. When the computer is switched back on, the desktop is restored exactly as it was.
A member of a dimension whose value is calculated at run time by using an expression. Calculated member values can be derived from the values of other members.

A secondary data source that is accessible to users who fill out forms offline. When a user is online, data from the data source is stored on the user’s computer so that it can appear in controls when the form is offline.
A field you can create. A custom field can be a blank, combination, or formula field.
To start or reset a computer by turning the power on, by pressing a reset button on the computer case, or by issuing a software command to restart.

The engine at the core of managed code execution. The runtime supplies managed code with services such as cross-language integration, code access security, object lifetime management, and debugging and profiling support.
A protocol that establishes the security association and shared keys necessary for computers to communicate by using Internet Protocol security (IPsec).
To prevent the writing (recording) of information, usually on a disk.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A graphic element on a drawing that is associated with data.
A visual cue to indicate which formatting will be applied when you double-click: a left-aligned, centered, or right-aligned tab stop; a left indent; or left or right text wrapping.
A list of the captions for pictures, charts, graphs, slides, or other illustrations in a document, along with the numbers of the pages the captions appear on.
To close a program or application.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A collection of masters associated with a particular Visio drawing type, or template. By default, stencils that open with a template are docked on the left side of the drawing window.
A fundamental data type that holds large integers. A Long variable is stored as a 32-bit number ranging in value from -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647.

The feature in Internet Explorer that remembers the information you have typed into the Address bar, web forms, or password fields, and which automatically fills in that information if you start to type the same thing again later.
Text or graphics inserted in a document when Microsoft Word carries out a field's instructions. When you print the document or hide field codes, the field results replace the field codes.
A unique name that identifies a user account to operating system. An account's user name must be unique among the other group names and user names within its own domain or workgroup.

A drop-down list box control on a data access page that retrieves records from an underlying recordset based on the value you select from the list. On a grouped page, the control retrieves a specific group of records.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A directory or folder made available to users over the network.
The process of confirming that data passing into the system is correct and complies with predefined rules, definitions, or parameters.
Any fixed or removable objects that store computer data. Examples include hard disks, floppy disks, tapes, and compact discs.
In the printing and display of characters on the screen, an imaginary horizontal line with which the base of each character, excluding descenders, is aligned.
A substitution that occurs when Windows or your printer uses a font similar to the one you used in your publication to display or print your publication.
A group of computers or other devices, such as printers and scanners, that communicate either wirelessly or by using a physical connection, such as an Ethernet cable or a phone line.
An item on the user's My Status menu. This is a status the user can select to indicate that they are currently busy.
An item on the Control Panel.
A profile that contains the data needed for translating the values of a color gamut. This data includes information about color, hue, saturation, and brightness.
An animation effect that specifies how the display changes as a user moves from one item (such as a slide or Web page) to another.
An animation effect that specifies how the display changes as a user moves from one item (such as a slide or Web page) to another.

The name of a set of members in a dimension hierarchy such that all members of the set are at the same distance from the root of the hierarchy. For example, a time hierarchy may contain the levels Year, Month, and Day.
One or more identifying lines printed at the top of a page. A header may contain a page number, a date, the author's name, and the document title, the name of chapter.
One or more identifying lines printed at the top of a page. A header may contain a page number, a date, the author's name, and the document title, the name of chapter.

The UI element that initiates the process of seeking a particular file or specific data. A search is carried out by a program through comparison or calculation to determine whether a match to some pattern exists or whether some other criteria have been met.
A person who is allowed to view and read content.
Displacement of the left or right edge of a block of text in relation to the margin or to other blocks of text.
Displacement of the left or right edge of a block of text in relation to the margin or to other blocks of text.
A picture or other object placed within a line of text that retains its place next to adjacent text when text is added or deleted.
A user-defined shortcut to the most commonly used forms, reports, websites, etc.
Pertaining to the delivery of information that combines different content formats, such as video, audio, still images, graphics, animation, and text.
A feature of e-mail programs that allows a user to send a copy of an e-mail message to a recipient without notifying other recipients that this was done.
A feature of e-mail programs that allows a user to send a copy of an e-mail message to a recipient without notifying other recipients that this was done.

In DNS, each part of a DNS domain name that represents a node in the domain namespace tree. For example, the three labels example, microsoft, and com make up the DNS domain name example.microsoft.com. Each label used in a DNS name cannot exceed 63 octets, 255 bytes including the terminating dot, for the fully qualified domain name (FQDN).
A list of options from which a user can choose. The options can be represented as text or graphics. A menu can contain other menus (submenus).
A pointed input device that comes with a mobile device or tablet PC, and is used to navigate through applications and to input information.
A pointed input device that comes with a mobile device or tablet PC, and is used to navigate through applications and to input information.
An option on Windows Parental Control that, if selected, creates logs of all the actions performed by a user on the computer.
A personal record of experiences, occurrances or proceedings, like a Baby Book or Life Book.
One of many sequential images that make up video or animation.
The exchange of text messages and computer files over a communications network, such as a local area network or the Internet.
The exchange of text messages and computer files over a communications network, such as a local area network or the Internet.
An object (such as a customer, item, or employee) that shares a set of defined attributes or characteristics, and that is used to manage rules for data.

termGrp.term: seòrsa na susbaint air an taobh a-muigh

descripGrp.descrip: A quick movement of a finger or pen on a screen that the computer interprets as a command, rather than as a mouse movement, writing, or drawing.
Pertaining to a file format that does not allow for VBA code. Office 12 default file formats are macro-free. Examples of file extensions for macro-free formats are .docx, .pptx, .xlsx.
As one aspect of a KPI, the desired level of performance with respect to a specific business goal or strategy. Actual values are evaluated against the target to determine KPI score and status.
A color that is defined by the operating system for a specific type of monitor and video adapter and that is associated with a specific part of the user interface, such as a window title or a menu.
The horizontal reference line on a grid, chart, or graph that has horizontal and vertical dimensions.
The horizontal reference line on a grid, chart, or graph that has horizontal and vertical dimensions.
To publish or write entries for a blog.

The ability to interpret vocal commands or convert spoken words into computer-readable text. Speech recognition programs enable you to control an application or enter text by speaking into a microphone, rather than by using a keyboard.
To update displayed information with current data.
A bar marked off in units of measure (such as inches) that is displayed across the top of the document window.
An image that appears as the background to a document. Generally faded and transparent, so that text can be clearly read over it.
A representation of facts, concepts or instructions in a formalized manner, suitable for communication, interpretation or processing.
A line that separates groups of controls (on a surface) or commands (on a menu).
A command button used in a toolbar (or status bar).
A cell range that you consolidate in the destination area you specify.
A database object that prints information formatted and organized according to your specifications.
One or more lines of text in the bottom margin area of a page. A footer may contain elements such as the page number, the name of the file, or the date.
A list that allows you to block a language encoding or character set in order to filter out unwanted international e-mail messages that display in a language you don't understand.
A string of text written in the command language and passed to the command interpreter for execution.
Additional information for the customer that should be informative but not essential to the task.
When referring to software, to remove program files and folders from the hard disk and remove related data from the registry so the software or solution is no longer available.
A list that allows you to block top-level domain names. Blocking country/region top-level domains allows you to filter unwanted e-mail messages you receive from specific countries or regions.
To do over again.

The process of changing the values in cells to see how those changes affect the outcome of formulas on a worksheet. For example, varying the interest rate that is used in an amortization table to determine the amount of the payments.
A handle that is displayed on some objects such as toolbars, tables, or on individual rows or columns, that allows the user to drag them to another location.
The area on the right side of the Windows taskbar. It contains shortcuts to programs and important status information.
A physical item for sale or purchase or available for license.
A box formed by the intersection of a row and a column in a worksheet or a table, in which you enter information.
The act of entering and editing text with a word processor.
An identifier in the form OLEServerName.ObjectName (for example, Excel.Sheet or PowerPoint.Slide) that's used by the Windows registry to uniquely identify an object.
An identifier in the form OLEServerName.ObjectName (for example, Excel.Sheet or PowerPoint.Slide) that's used by the Windows registry to uniquely identify an object.
To change the size of an element on the screen.
The display of data or an image from a given perspective or location.
A document describing a company's position on privacy, detailing what information it collects, with whom the data is shared, and how users can control the use of their personal information.
Text or some other element used in an application as an indicator that the user should enter in his or her own text.
A line that separates the numerator and denominator of a fraction.
A small space on the To-Do Bar where the user can input tasks directly. The default label reads "Type a new task".
Data from a table, form, query, view, or stored procedure, displayed in a row-and-column format.

A view that is designed for reading documents on a computer screen. The document is resized to fit the screen and most toolbars are removed, but commands are available for navigating, commenting, and looking up words.
Information about the reading level of a document in Word.
An optional Live Meeting tool that allows users to create Live Meeting slides and add a presenter photo as part of a Microsoft PowerPoint file.
A type of chart that compares the aggregate values of a number of data series.

A design template that also contains text suggestions on each slide. You replace the text suggestions with the text that you want. A content template contains a slide master and an optional title master.
To put new data in the place of other data, usually after conducting a search for the data to be replaced. Text-based applications such as word processors typically include Find and Replace commands.
Relating to frequencies within the range of perception by the human ear - from about 15 to 20,000 hertz (cycles per second).
A type of markup in markup languages. A start tag is the starting element of a tag pair which contains metainformation about some part of the text.
A button that opens Sync Center.
A user who can schedule meetings, send invitations, do all the sharing activities in a meeting, and admit participants from the lobby.
The width-to-height ratio of a video or still image, or of the screen on which an image is displayed.
The width-to-height ratio of a video or still image, or of the screen on which an image is displayed.
A feature of a computer or operating system that allows it to run programs written for a different system.

The area of the workspace that contains the options you select for a given task. Workpanes appear at certain times, such as when a document is opened, or when you click certain items on menus and toolbars.
A file that contains audio, video, or script data.
The data that is contained within a worksheet outline. Outline data includes both the summary and detail rows or columns of an outline.
A graphic or other object that is inserted in the drawing layer so that you can position it precisely on the page or in front of or behind text or other objects.
A toolbar that is part of an application when it's installed on your computer.
Malware that replicates, commonly by infecting other files in the system, thus allowing the execution of the malware code and its propagation when those files are activated.
A wireless implementation and the second generation of WPA security that is based on the final IEEE 802.11i amendment to the 802.11 standard.
Personal Area Networks (PAN) that communicate directly between one or more Bluetooth-enabled computers or devices.
An area in a browser or mail program that displays various information or messages for the user.
An area in a browser or mail program that displays various information or messages for the user.
A descriptive text string that identifies a page.
A sound that becomes audible to the user to trigger an action by the user.
To cause an application to display information on a computer or device screen.
A view that shows the headings of a document indented to represent their level in the document's structure. You can also use this view to work with master documents.
The one who sends an electronic message.
One of a set of cryptographic algorithms specified by the US National Security Agency to provide an interoperable standard for government and industry.
An item of a custom group field. A custom group contains two or more items from a row or column field.
A holding place for a group of linked documents or Works tasks / templates related to a single user activity.

A Post-Script file format that can be used as an independent entity. The EPS image must be incorporated into the Post-Script output of an application such as a desktop publisher. Many high-quality clip-art packages consist of such images.
An image that shows all or part of a computer screen or other display.

The order of evaluation (from highest to lowest solve order) and calculation (from lowest to highest solve order) for calculated members, custom members, custom rollup formulas, and calculated cells in a single calculation pass of a multidimensional cube.
A form contained within another form or a report.
To enlarge a selected portion of a graphical image or document to fill a window or the screen.
To enlarge a selected portion of a graphical image or document to fill a window or the screen.

A Regional and Language Options setting that specifies the default code pages and associated bitmap font files for a specific computer that affects all of that computer's users. The default code pages and fonts enable a non-Unicode application written for one operating system language version to run correctly on another operating system language version.

termGrp.term: An cànan airson prògraman nach cleachd Unicode

descripGrp.descrip: The list of animation sequences for a slide. Items are listed in the order in which they are added, and include icons that indicate timing in relation to other animation events.
A monitoring option in real-time spyware protection that monitors various types and areas of software activity on your computer.

A row, column, or block of buttons or icons, usually displayed across the top of the screen, that represent tasks or commands within the program. The toolbar buttons provide shortcuts to common tasks frequently accessed from the menus.
A formula that performs multiple calculations on one or more sets of values, and then returns either a single result or multiple results.

A chart that is placed on a worksheet rather than on a separate chart sheet. Embedded charts are beneficial when you want to view or print a chart or a PivotChart report with its source data or other information in a worksheet.
A graphic or diagram that displays data or the relationships between sets of data in pictorial rather than numeric form.

Pertaining to a user who, during business hours (or at any time if no business hours have been set), is not signed in to any Lync or Communicator, or IM device and cannot be contacted by phone (no call forwarding information is published).
A list that can be opened to reveal all choices for a given field.
A category of objects that share a common set of characteristics.
A quantity assigned to an element such as a variable, symbol, or label.
To store data in such a way that it can be retrieved later by the same security support component, and only by that security support component.
An option that applies a read-only state to a document inside client applications.
To associate a flag with a message or other item.
A software program that reduces a file's size for storage on a disk. If a compressed file is too large to fit onto a single disk, the compression utility copies it onto multiple disks.
Erroneous or unrecognizable because of a flaw in reasoning or an error in input. Invalid results, for example, might occur if the logic in a program is faulty.
A computational proof that Outlook applies to outgoing messages to help recipient messaging systems distinguish legitimate e-mail from junk e-mail.
A menu item in Internet Explorer that turns on the tool for Tablet PC users that allows the user to move the content of the page up and down, like a mouse scroll wheel.
The pane in normal view in which you type notes that you want to accompany a slide. You print these notes as notes pages or have them display when you save a presentation as a Web page.
The activities and actions performed by customer service representatives to assist customers.
A unit of work that is represented to users in the form of buttons, links, and menu items.
To move an item to a higher level within a tree structure.
The / character.
The 802.11b standard for wireless networking. A standard for delivering digital information over high-frequency, wireless local area networks.

The server name, user name, password, and e-mail address used to connect to an e-mail service. You create the e-mail account using information provided by your mail administrator or Internet service provider (ISP).
To create a user session for an Internet account. For example, you sign in to a Microsoft account, an Internet service provider account, or Skype.
A single media file, including art, sound, animation, or movies.
A single media file, including art, sound, animation, or movies.
To enroll in a service, often resulting in setting up a new account.
A case distinction in which every word's first chararacter is uppercase and the remaining letters are lower case.
A field code that marks specific text for inclusion in an index. When you mark text as an index entry, Microsoft Office Word inserts an XE (Index Entry) field formatted as hidden text.
A range of cells that shows how changing certain values in your formulas affects the results of the formulas.
To insert content, such as text or a graphic, that has been cut or copied from one document into a different location in the same or a different document.
A program that creates files or makes changes to existing files.
A system that sends and receives messages in the form of sound recordings.
To identify or designate with a label; describe or classify.
To make a duplicate copy of a program, a disk, or data.
A cell in a layout table.

Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, and languages for which text is displayed in a left-to-right direction. English and most other European languages are left-to-right languages.
A control in Windows that enables the user to choose one option from a list of possibilities.
The part of a hyperlink in a document or Web page that displays as text on the screen.
A movable piece on a device that is pressed to activate some function.
A view of a document as it will appear when you print it.
The content that is delivered in an e-mail message.
The digital signature functionality including Digital Signatures, electronic signatures, Mark As Final and Electronic Postmarks.
A color that is not part of a color scheme.
A color that is not part of a color scheme.
A set of graphics, text, and colors for defining different levels of performance when comparing an actual value and a target value within a KPI.
A UI command used to switch between accounts on a device.
The overall plan or design of a document system.
In computer design, the arrangement of circuits and other components of the system.
Pertaining to characters that are formatted to appear darker and heavier than the surrounding text.

The electronic components that generate the video signal sent through a cable to a video display. The video adapter is usually located on the computer's main system board or on an expansion board, but it is sometimes built into the terminal.

The electronic components that generate the video signal sent through a cable to a video display. The video adapter is usually located on the computer's main system board or on an expansion board, but it is sometimes built into the terminal.
A unit of information transmitted as a whole from one device to another on a network.

Code that is executed by the common language runtime environment rather than directly by the operating system. Managed code applications gain common language runtime services such as automatic garbage collection, runtime type checking and security support, and so on. These services help provide uniform platform- and language-independent behavior of managed-code applications.

Part of the integrated Routing and Remote Access service that provides remote networking for telecommuters, mobile workers, and system administrators who monitor and manage servers at multiple branch offices. Users can use Network Connections to dial in to remotely access their networks for services such as file and printer sharing, electronic mail, scheduling, and SQL database access.
A method of real-time communication over the Internet in which a sender types a message to one or more recipients and the recipient immediately receives the message in a chat area.
A method of real-time communication over the Internet in which a sender types a message to one or more recipients and the recipient immediately receives the message in a chat area.
A connection between the user's device and a server that provides access to the Internet, typically through an Internet service provider.
A tool that helps you create or edit a formula and also provides information about functions and their arguments.
A tool that helps you create or edit a formula and also provides information about functions and their arguments.
The area of the Query window that displays the tables in a query. Each table displays the fields from which you can retrieve data.
In a PivotTable report, the summarized data calculated from the data fields of a source list or table.
A sequence of shades ranging from black through white, used in computer graphics to add detail to images or to represent a color image on a monochrome output device.
To scan a database, a list of files, or the Internet, either for a particular item or for anything that seems to be of interest.
Light that is beyond red in the color spectrum. While the light is not visible to the human eye, infrared transmitters and receivers can send and receive infrared signals.

A feature that enables records managers to create and manage entries to a “Holds list” such that any document, image, or webpage on that list cannot be deleted, modified, or allowed to expire until the item is removed from the list. The feature is typically used for items that are subject to events such as litigation, audits, or investigations.
A set of files that can be delivered as a unit to a client computer or device for installation.
A Control Panel feature that is used to set restrictions on what traffic is allowed to enter your network from the Internet.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
Any of the set of words that comprises a given programming language or set of operating-system routines.
The location where text or graphics will be inserted. Also used for text box controls to indicate input focus.
A status that can be applied to blocks of time in a user's Calendar to indicate that the user will be away.
The color against which characters and graphics are displayed.
Pertaining to items that occur repeatedly. For example, an appointment or task that occurs on a regular basis, such as a weekly status meeting or a monthly haircut, can be designated as recurring.
A list that includes the e-mail addresses of mailing lists for which you want to be a recipient. Messages sent to such a mailing list and received by you will not be treated as junk e-mail.

A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely. To do this, DEP software works alone or with compatible microprocessors to mark some memory locations as "non-executable." If a program tries to run code that is malicious or is not from a protected location, DEP closes the program and notifies you.

A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely. To do this, DEP software works alone or with compatible microprocessors to mark some memory locations as "non-executable." If a program tries to run code that is malicious or is not from a protected location, DEP closes the program and notifies you.
The consistent positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
A virtual shape that contains default formatting properties for new shapes. Each presentation contains one default shape.
The degree to which a product or service executes its specified function.
A window in which you work with queries in Design view, Datasheet view, SQL view, or Print Preview.
A printed page that displays author notes beneath the slide that the notes accompany.

On a keyboard, the combination of a plastic keycap, a tension mechanism that suspends the keycap but allows it to be pressed down, and an electronic mechanism that records the key press and key release.
In respect to privacy, an individual's ability to view, modify, and contest the accuracy and completeness of PII collected about him or her. Access is an element of the Fair Information Practices.
An outlined container that displays a markup element, such as a comment or revision, in the margin of a document.
An outlined container that displays a markup element, such as a comment or revision, in the margin of a document.
To activate an application program (especially on the Macintosh) from the operating system's user interface.
The original plan for a project, a work package, or an activity.

A list created to apply a hierarchical structure to any list or document. A document can have up to nine levels, and Microsoft Office Word does not apply built-in heading styles to the items in the list.
Header and footer information, or header information only, which encapsulates or precedes document data for transport.
A forum on the Internet for discussions on a specified range of subjects.
Technology that enables rendering operations to be handled by the client.
Technology that enables rendering operations to be handled by the client.
A software product that acts as a server for one or more services. Typically, a server product would be installed on a server machine (hardware), and provide services to users over the network.
In a DVD or a video, a portion of a title, such as a scene or sequence. A title can contain one or more chapters.

A pane that displays document property information for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files stored in a WSS library. The pane is displayed below the ribbon and is actually a hosted custom InfoPath form. Information is synced automatically between the document and the WSS library.

A pane that displays document property information for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files stored in a WSS library. The pane is displayed below the ribbon and is actually a hosted custom InfoPath form. Information is synced automatically between the document and the WSS library.
The smallest executable entity within a programming language.
A compact disc containing audio information (as opposed to a CD-ROM containing data and files).
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A named storage area on a computer or device containing files and other folders. Folders are used to organize information electronically, the same way actual folders in a filing cabinet do.
Text objects you create with ready-made effects to which you can apply additional formatting options.
A button that directs the user to the Home section of an application.
The text that forms the major content of a publication. Does not include titles, headlines, pull quotes, and captions, for example.
A rectangular control in an application that allows the user to enter or edit text.
A rectangular control in an application that allows the user to enter or edit text.
To convert encrypted content back into its original form.
A predefined combination of grouped and sorted messages in table view.
A high definition optical disc format which uses a smaller focus blue-violet 405 nm laser allowing higher precision and storage density. A competitor to Blu-ray Disc.
To arrange to receive a product or use a service regularly.
To make a record, file, or other data available in the system.
A character that separates items in a list.
In Windows-based systems, a unique value that identifies a user, group, or computer account within an enterprise. Every account is issued a SID when it is created.
An Internet protocol used for sending electronic mail.
A camera for use with a computer to transmit a video picture.
A feature that enables the user to create, manage and apply standardized citations and references in a document.
To find.

Components that can be installed on your computer to add commands and functions to Excel. These add-in programs are specific to Excel. Other add-in programs that are available for Excel or Office are Component Object Model (COM) add-ins.
A digital interface specification for delivering digital content and connecting consumer electronic devices.

A person, inside or outside your organization, for whom you have created an entry where you can save several types of information, such as street and e-mail addresses, telephone and fax numbers, and Web page URLs.
The device that communicates between your software program and your printer.

Antispyware software included in Windows that can prevent other software from displaying advertisements (such as pop-up ads), collect information about you, or change settings on your computer, generally without appropriately obtaining your consent.
A file containing data where individual field values are separated by a character, such as a comma or a tab.
A tool that lets you enter complex characters and symbols, such as those used in East Asian written languages, using a standard keyboard.
A tool that lets you enter complex characters and symbols, such as those used in East Asian written languages, using a standard keyboard.
A diagram that is used to show areas of overlap between and among elements.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.

A list that includes the name of the person who originally sent a task request plus the names of everyone who received the task request, reassigned the task to someone else, or chose to keep an updated copy of the task in their task list.

A line printed above, below, or to the side of some element, either to set that item off from the remainder of the page or to improve the look of the page. Footnotes, for example, often appear below a short rule that sets them off from the main text on the page. The thickness of a rule is typically measured in points. (A point is approximately 1/72 inch.)
The information about a computer that's derived from the System Information program.
A set of items or devices working together to accomplish a task.
The slide that stores information from the design template pertaining to styles on title slides, including placeholder sizes and positions, background design, and color schemes.
A networking standard that uses cables to provide network access. Ethernet is the most widely installed technology for connecting computers.

A character-encoding standard developed by the Unicode Consortium that represents almost all of the written languages of the world. The Unicode character repertoire has multiple representation forms, including UTF-8, UTF-16, and UTF-32. Most Windows interfaces use the UTF-16 form.

A type of display that uses a liquid compound having a polar molecular structure, sandwiched between two transparent electrodes. When an electric field is applied, the molecules align with the field, forming a crystalline arrangement that polarizes the light passing through it. A polarized filter laminated over the electrodes blocks polarized light. In this way, a grid of electrodes can selectively "turn on" a cell, or a pixel, containing the liquid crystal material, turning it dark.
A reference to a range that spans two or more worksheets in a workbook.
A unique bank registration number that a bank uses to identify itself.
A unique bank registration number that a bank uses to identify itself.
A keyboard key that sends the escape (ESC) character to the computer. Often this key moves the user back one level in the menu structure or exits the program.
A customer's right to control how and to what extent their personal information is collected and used and with whom it is shared.
An identification number that is issued by a tax authority to indicate that a company is not required to pay sales tax.
An IP address of the OneNote session that is being shared with other users.
A feature that identifies people using computers near you so that you can use features and programs that use peer-to-peer technology.
Any device that changes electrical signals or computer data from one form to another. For example, an analog-to-digital converter translates analog signals to digital signals.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.
The amount of light that is emitted by a computer monitor or picture displayed on the monitor.
An application that is used to open an attachment for Attachment Previewing.

In an environment capable of displaying multiple on-screen windows, any window other than the one currently being used for work. An inactive window can be partially or entirely hidden behind another window, and it remains inactive until the user selects it.

An e-mail folder with associated retention, archive, or expiration policies that are applied to its contents. Organizations can facilitate policy enforcement by providing such folders for users to classify e-mail messages.
A database query and programming language widely used for accessing, querying, updating, and managing data in relational database systems.

To duplicate information and reproduce it in another part of a document, in a different file or memory location, or in a different medium. A copy operation can affect data ranging from a single character to large segments of text, a graphics image, or from one to many data files.
A directory that you can use to store names, e-mail addresses, fax numbers, and distribution lists.
The consistent vertical positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
A card-like layout on an Outlook Contact that provides the user with the look of a real world business card.
A card-like layout on an Outlook Contact that provides the user with the look of a real world business card.
In 2-D stacked bar and column charts, a line that connects the data markers in a data series and is used to emphasize the difference in measurement between each series.
The pairing of two or more actions that are performed together as a single action; the action succeeds or fails as a whole.
To displace the left or right edge of a text item, such as a block or a line, relative to the margin or to another text item.

For automatic subtotals and worksheet outlines, the subtotal rows or columns that are totaled by summary data. Detail data is typically adjacent to and either above or to the left of the summary data.

An operation that retrieves rows from multiple source tables by comparing the values from columns shared between the source tables. An inner join excludes rows from a source table that have no matching rows in the other source tables.
An Office feature that allows users to create professional looking information graphics quickly and easily.
Two arrows in shape of a cross, with two heads each pointing in opposite directions.
To place a file or project back in a source repository. This releases the lock for editing and enables other users to view the updated file or check out the file.
The practice of recording, classifying, summarizing, and reporting the financial consequences of accounting events.
The processor in an imagesetter or desktop printer that interprets the commands sent by a printer driver and converts them to a raster or bitmap grid to mark the paper or film.
A combination of table formatting options identified by a style name.
A feature that enables the user to access Outlook data over the Internet without a VPN connection.
Software that is used to compress or decompress a digital media file.
Someone granted permission to access items or perform functions on another user's behalf.

The name of a pane at the bottom of the Calendar module where tasks are displayed. Tasks that are completed on a particular day "stick" to the day and are shown as a record of what work was performed on that day. Tasks not completed roll over to the next day and accumulate until completed.
A field that is assigned a series orientation in a PivotChart report. In a chart, series are represented in the legend.
A note alongside the main text that contains interesting or useful information.
The blank space outside the printing area on a page.

A special AutoText entry that stores multiple deletions. Microsoft Office Word appends one item to another until you paste the contents as a group in a new location in your document. You can also use the Microsoft Office Clipboard to get the same result.
A sequence of averages computed from parts of a data series. In a chart, a moving average smooths the fluctuations in data, thus showing the pattern or trend more clearly.
To make a form, view, device or other resource available over a network.

Information displayed to a user about someone else adding him or her to a contact list, a contact's offline or online status, a missed conversation, voice mail message, service problem, or other item.
A miniature version of an image that is often used for quick browsing through multiple images.
A miniature version of an image that is often used for quick browsing through multiple images.
A dictionary with words that the main dictionary recognizes as being spelled correctly, but that you want to verify during a spelling check.
The top level of a business hierarchy.
An independent section on a webpage. Each frame is actually a separate webpage and can have its own scrollbars.
A spreadsheet that contains information about a shape; for example, its dimensions, angle, and center of rotation and the styles that determine the shape's appearance.
Tasks that a user is permitted to perform on a computer system or domain.
A series of instructions that is repeated a fixed number of times or until a terminating condition is reached.

In general, a modular unit of code that acts as part of a larger system or structure. For COM, a unit of code built to deliver a well-specified set of services through well-specified interfaces. A component provides an object that a client requests at runtime.
In an online forum, such as a newsgroup, a series of messages or articles in which replies to an message are nested directly under it instead of arranged in chronological or alphabetical order.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.
A technology that is based on the Component Object Model (COM) that enables interoperability among ActiveX components, including OLE components. Formerly referred to as OLE Automation.
A feature that consists of advanced text wrap functionality, allowing the user to select from various styles to specify how text flows around objects or graphics in a document.
The process of breaking a word between syllables at the end of a line or to separate the parts of a compound word.

An encryption algorithm that uses a 56-bit key and maps a 64-bit input block to a 64-bit output block. The key appears to be a 64-bit key, but one bit in each of the eight bytes is used for odd parity, resulting in 56 bits of usable key.

Total values for all cells in a row or all cells in a column of a PivotTable report. Values in a grand total row or column are calculated by using the same summary function used in the data area of the PivotTable report.

descripGrp.descrip: A mode that enables the user to move a document by dragging it. Panning mode is available when a Word document is displayed on a preview pane.

An enhanced spell-check feature that looks at words before or after the word in question to assess proper usage. This allows the software to flag correctly-spelled words as 'wrong' if the usage appears to be incorrect.
A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.
A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.

termGrp.term: World Wide Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning
World Wide Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning

descripGrp.descrip: A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.
A session in which multiple users can work together and see each other’s changes immediately.
A session in which multiple users can work together and see each other’s changes immediately.
An external file included with an e-mail message.
An account number scheme that is recognized by banks internationally to facilitate credit transfers across national/regional borders.
An area of the window that displays a limited view of search results or other content.
A specific Office icon that is used within a group to launch a related dialog box.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.
Information that Outlook uses to remember the e-mail accounts and the settings that tell Outlook where your e-mail is stored.
A collection of binaries that can be installed on top of the core product and enables users to select a preferred language so that the user interface and Help files appear in that preferred language.

A common programming interface to the lower-level system area network (SAN) implementations, developed by Microsoft. WSD sits underneath the standard WinSock application programming interface (API), but bypasses the kernel networking layers to talk directly to the SAN hardware. Because WSD sits underneath the existing WinSock API, IT departments can deploy applications in a SAN environment without modifying the applications.
A collection of files, managed by a manifest.xml file, that add functionality to a Microsoft Office Word or Microsoft Office Excel document by specifying custom display or actions.
A sequence of declarations and statements that are executed as a unit.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.

A temporary property of a user-interface object, such as a window, view, dialog box, or button, that permits the object to receive keyboard input from the user. The focus is usually conveyed through highlighting.
A user dictionary that contains a list of words not in the application dictionary that an author wants the spelling checker to accept as correct.
A formula syntax that allows the user to refer to list and pivot data in a friendlier way.
A classification for grouping content by user-defined criteria such as page contents, file types, or a similar distinction.

A stand-alone, dynamic-link library that, when loaded, can add custom commands that extend the functionality of Microsoft Word. Commands and functions in a loaded WLL are also available to Microsoft Visual Basic projects.

A stand-alone, dynamic-link library that, when loaded, can add custom commands that extend the functionality of Microsoft Word. Commands and functions in a loaded WLL are also available to Microsoft Visual Basic projects.
A button on the address bar that enables the user to navigate to the specified location (such as a folder path or web address).
A person whose work or profession is management.
Having values separated from each other by tabs.
Having values separated from each other by tabs.
A value shown in Excel when there is an error in a formula, for example #VALUE! or #REF!.
The state of an uninitialized Variant variable (which returns a VarType of 0).
A set of formatting characteristics that you can apply to text, tables, and lists in your document to quickly change their appearance.
A name that uniquely identifies a server computer on a network.
To display only the rows in a list that satisfy the conditions you specify. You use the AutoFilter command to display rows that match one or more specific values, calculated values, or conditions.

An 8-byte, fixed-point data type that is useful for calculations involving money or for fixed-point calculations in which accuracy is extremely important. The Currency data type is used to store numbers with up to 15 digits to the left of the decimal point and 4 digits to the right. The type-declaration character in Microsoft© Visual Basic© is an at sign (@). Currency can range from -922,337,203,685,477.5808 to 922,337,203,685,477.5807.
A 16-bit vector graphics format for Windows-compatible computers used mostly as a clip art format in word-processing documents.

A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics rather than magnetic means for reading data. Optical disk storage commonly used for audio, video, and computer data. DVDs range in capacity from 4.7 GB to 17 GB, and can store significantly more than a CD-ROM.
The accuracy of data and its conformity to its expected value, especially after being transmitted or processed.
Software used to scan for and eradicate computer viruses, worms, and trojan horses.
An image that has been captured electronically with a digital camera or scanner.
An image that has been captured electronically with a digital camera or scanner.
The inability to perform two or more activities because they have been scheduled to occur during the same time period and with the same resource or resources.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
To attach a label to.
To wait for incoming traffic, calls or connection requests on a port.
To be unresponsive.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.
A list of domain names and e-mail addresses that are treated as junk e-mail and are blocked unless the sender is on the Safe Senders List or the recipient is on the Safe Recipients List.
A copy of a master, which you create by dragging the master from a stencil to a drawing.
An item in the Journal folder that acts as a shortcut to an activity that has been recorded.

The Book.xlt template that you create to change the default format of new workbooks. Excel uses the template to create a blank workbook when you start Excel or create a new workbook without specifying a template.
To activate or turn on.
A visual display of data in a dashboard that can be coordinated with other report views by using filters.
A color that is mixed with black. A 10-percent shade is one part of the original color and nine parts black.
Settings that enable parents to restrict what their children see.
Combined earphone and microphone set that enables hands-free communication.
The slide text on the slide master. The master text determines the format of text on all slides as well as the shape of text placeholders and their placement on slides.
The naming convention for disk drives or partitions on most computers, consisting of an alphabetical letter followed by a colon.
An icon that designates a change made by a reviewer to a presentation.
A second calendar format selected by the user from within Outlook and visible in dual calendar view.
A sequence of words or other text used to gain access to a network, program, or data. A passphrase is generally longer for added security.
A task pane with options that enable the user to send a Publisher file as personalized, individually addressed e-mail to the recipients in the specified list.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal to one sixth of an inch.
A OneNote item that has been marked with a note tag.
A configuration parameter or element that controls the behavior of a service, application, feature, function, or a run-time environment.
A route through a structured collection of information, as in a database, a program, or files stored on disk.
To align text along the right margin.
The area in each row of a database table that stores the data value for some attribute of the object modeled by the table.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
The protection of information assets through the use of technology, processes, and training.
The point at which one page ends and another begins.
A method computers use to send and receive e-mail messages. It allows you to access e-mail without downloading it to your computer or device.

A Microsoft Exchange mailbox that allocates a specific number of connections. The resource serves as a virtual room for your online meeting. You invite the resource to an online meeting just as you would reserve a room for a meeting.
A menu choice or remote button that offers access to the user's video library.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer. Permissions must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer. Permissions must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.
An option that changes a 2-dimensional linear expression, such as 5^2, to a built-up (3-dimensional) format.
A reference to a specific legal case, statute, or other legal document.
A person who is involved in the creation of content. For example editors, technical reviewers and subject matter experts are contributors.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
A dialog box that allows users to add/remove/organize the list of bibliographic information for the document
The combination of a number of products for sale as one unit.
The text of a WordArt object.
A network within an organization that uses Internet technologies and protocols, but is available only to certain people, such as employees of a company.
A person whose information, such as ID or email address, has been added by the user to their contact list or to an address book.
The horizontal arrangement of cells in a table or spreadsheet.
A summary of one's academic and work history, usually submitted with a job application.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
A menu option on the Property Panel that enables the user to specify document properties.
To end an application's relationship with an open file so that the application will no longer be able to access the file without opening it again.
A symbol that is displayed beside a paragraph in outline view. You can use the symbol to display or hide subordinate levels of text and to reorganize text quickly.
A complete Web site stored in a named subdirectory of the top-level Web site.
A symbol selected to designate a specific currency.
The way text is displayed in a document, how it behaves and breaks according to settings.
On a disk or other direct-access storage device, a continuous block of storage space reserved by the operating system for a particular file or program.
The writing or drawing strokes that you make with your stylus.
The writing or drawing strokes that you make with your stylus.
A mark inserted in a document to show where a comment has been added.
A field that contains a contact's mobile phone number.
The ? character, used as a punctuation mark or wildcard character.

A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email. An email address on the Internet typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.

A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email. An email address on the Internet typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.

A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email. An email address on the Internet typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.

A set of conditions and associated actions that may be applied to certain tasks. For example, an email rule might stipulate that all messages from a particular sender be placed into a specific folder.

A set of conditions and associated actions that may be applied to certain tasks. For example, an email rule might stipulate that all messages from a particular sender be placed into a specific folder.
To send a received e-mail message or calendar item, either modified or in its entirety, to a new recipient.
A client program or control that receives digital media content streamed from a server or played from local files. Windows Media Player is an example of a player.
The portion of an on-screen file that has been marked as subject to user action.
The Microsoft web browser.
A file or set of files that defines the data structure, appearance, and behavior of a form.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A computer that provides shared resources, such as files or printers, to network users.
A number that identifies each telephone service area in a country/region and is used as a dialing prefix.
To configure a device or application so that it performs better. For example, to fine-tune a program so that it runs more quickly or takes up less space.
A software control that incorporates ActiveX technology.
A graph that uses horizontal bars to illustrate comparisons among individual data items.
A graph that uses horizontal bars to illustrate comparisons among individual data items.
A picture made from a series of small dots, much like a piece of graph paper with certain squares filled in to form shapes and lines.
Pertaining to a type of access to data in a database that is shared over a network. When you open a database in exclusive mode, you prevent others from opening the database.
A supplemental program that can extend the capabilities of an application program.
To tap twice quickly on a screen or touchpad.
To adjust the perspective of an image or document in order to view a larger area on the screen at one time, as if viewed from farther away.

A menu choice in many applications that allows the user to specify how the program will act each time it is used. For example, the user may be allowed to specify which view will be used when opening a file, or the default location in which certain file types will be saved.
The sheet that you're working on in a workbook. The name on the tab of the active sheet is bold.
A customizable toolbar that provides one-click access to commands.

A card, plug, or other device that connects pieces of hardware with the computer so that information can be moved from place to place. For example, standardized interfaces such as RS-232-C standard and SCSI enable communications between computers and printers or disks.
A setting in which existing characters are replaced with newly typed characters.
The capability of many programs and operating systems to display advice or instructions for using their features when so requested by the user, as by a screen button or menu item or a function key.

In facsimile and other optical technologies, to move a light-sensitive device across an image-bearing surface such as a page of text, converting the light and dark areas on the surface to binary digits that can be interpreted by a computer.
A small graphical symbol the user can insert into instant messages.
An individual song or other discrete piece of audio content.

A button that represents an item or program that is open and running on your computer. For example, if you open Microsoft Word, and then minimize it, it will be displayed as a taskbar button, which you can then click when you want to maximize it.

To detect, locate, and correct logical or syntactical errors in a program or malfunctions in hardware. In hardware contexts, the term troubleshoot is the term more often used, especially when the problem is a major one.

A testing process that supplies structured but invalid input to software application programming interfaces (APIs) and network interfaces to maximize the likelihood of detecting errors that might lead to software vulnerabilities.
A microphone feature that allows your input to be amplified so that it is made louder for use by the system.
An executable program file that contains one or more compressed text or data files. When a user runs the program, it uncompresses the compressed files and stores them on the user's hard drive.

Of or relating to communications systems in which the medium of transmission (such as a wire or fiber-optic cable) carries multiple messages at a time, each message modulated on its own carrier frequency by a modem.
The Windows technology that collects data on system crashes or hangs and sends it to Microsoft.
To mark text, cells, and similar items that will be subject to a user action, such as copying text.
A menu item that allows the play back all of the items in a playlist once, in random order. Playback ends when all of the items in the list have been played one time.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.

The process of seeking a particular file or specific data. A search is carried out by a program through comparison or calculation to determine whether a match to some pattern exists or whether some other criteria have been met.
Part of the Office Center feature that allows users to set various security and privacy options, and to see currently enforced security and privacy rules.
To move the pointer over a UI element for a specified duration with the intent of interacting with that element.
Completed or passed. The measured duration of an event.
A handheld portable telephone that operates through a radio network.
To move an object one pixel at a time.
A repository that is separate from the user’s mailbox and that allows items to be archived on the server.
A field that's assigned a row orientation in a PivotTable report. Items associated with a row field are displayed as row labels.
The slide master and title master for a given design template that you have applied to a presentation.
The area of the window that displays the criteria used to limit the records included in the result set of your query.
The basic building block of a macro; a self-contained instruction that can be combined with other actions to automate tasks. This is sometimes called a command in other macro languages.
A room, computer, or any equipment needed at a meeting.
The areas surrounding many 3-D chart types that give dimension and boundaries to the chart. Two walls and one floor are displayed within the plot area.

A message that has been sent across one or more messaging systems. It may have been sent only to you or to many other recipients. Incoming messages are placed in a receive folder designated to hold messages of a particular class. You can set up a different receive folder for each message class that you handle or use one folder for all of the classes.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.
To prepare a disk, computer or device for use.

The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions. Mainframes and early minicomputers contained circuit boards full of integrated circuits that implemented the CPU. Single-chip central processing units, called microprocessors, made possible personal computers and workstations.

The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions. Mainframes and early minicomputers contained circuit boards full of integrated circuits that implemented the CPU. Single-chip central processing units, called microprocessors, made possible personal computers and workstations.
A commercial organization or a small business.
An alphanumeric code assigned to all addresses in order to facilitate mail delivery.
A combination of a digital certificate and a public and private encryption key set.
The list or table that's used to create a PivotTable or PivotChart report. Source data can be taken from an Excel list or range, an external database or cube, or another PivotTable report.
To add a digital signature to a macro or file.
A peripheral device whose purpose is to allow the user to provide input to a computer system. Examples of input devices are keyboards, mice, joysticks, and styluses.
One character (or more) that is slightly higher than other text on a line, such as a footnote reference mark.
A Windows technology that protects OS resources (files, folders registry keys) and prevents applications and administrators from making changes to a computer's resources in an arbitrary way.

A chart that provides interactive analysis of data, like a PivotTable report. You can change views of data, see different levels of detail, or reorganize the chart layout by dragging fields and by showing or hiding items in fields.
Usually 1,048,576 bytes. It is sometimes interpreted as 1 million bytes.
Usually 1,048,576 bytes. It is sometimes interpreted as 1 million bytes.
In computing, a characteristic of data that is represented as binary digits (zeros and ones).
To make a transmission appear to come from a user other than the user who performed the action.
A diagramming capability that shows charts in three dimensions.
To adjust horizontal spacing so that text is aligned evenly along both the left and right margins. Justifying text creates a smooth edge on both sides.
A change made to a file or a document.
A file that saves display information about open workbooks, so that you can later resume work with the same window sizes, print areas, screen magnification, and display settings.
To set a variable to an initial value.
Amusment, pleasure, or diversion.
A calendar item that includes reserved resources and/or invited attendees.
A frequently updated online journal or column.
A legal agreement between a software or hardware manufacturer and the end user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of the software.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.
A link via wire, radio, fiber-optic cable, or other medium between two or more communications devices.
A device used to connect wireless computers and other wireless devices to a wired network.
To end a user session for an Internet account. For example, you sign out of a Microsoft account, an Internet service provider account, or Skype.

Any shape that you draw by using the Curve, Freeform, and Scribble tools. Freeform shapes can include straight lines and freehand curves. They can be drawn opened or closed and can be edited by using the drawing tools.
Hearing impairment that results in complete loss of hearing.
A framework that includes rows and columns for organizing and arranging content on a form, including controls, control labels, sections of a form, logos, and other types of graphics.

Paragraph formatting you can use to assign a hierarchical level (Level 1 through Level 9) to paragraphs in your document. For example, after you assign outline levels, you can work with the document in outline view or in the Document Map.
A general class of software used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
A general class of software used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
A symbol used to represent the Control key on the keyboard. For example, ^Z means "hold the Control key down and press the Z key."
To change an existing row of data in the data store or to transmit pending changes to the data store.
The last line of a paragraph printed by itself at the top of a page.
The data type that holds a maximum of 8,000 characters.
An action statement in any computer language, most often in machine or assembly language. Most programs consist of two types of statements: declarations and instructions.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
