A common Windows control that displays and sets a value from a continuous range of possible values, such as brightness or volume.
To reduce a window to a button on the taskbar by clicking the Minimize button (leftmost button on the right side of the title bar) or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing N.
A single location in Windows where you can adjust mobile PC settings.
A file that contains encoded information that is interpreted according to the application that created it. In general, a binary file can be edited only by the application in which it was created.
An interactive technology in Microsoft Excel or Access that can show dynamic views of the same data from a list or a database.

A Microsoft Office Web Component that allows you to create a structure similar to an Excel PivotTable report. Users can view the PivotTable list in a Web browser and change its layout in a manner similar to an Excel PivotTable report.
Confidence in the reliability of an entity or service and the information that it provides.
A user interface control that facilitates modification of an object's appearance, position, or behavior.
The date by which some task or action should be completed.

A graphic element that appears similar to a physical button or keyboard key in the UI. A button is "pressed" by clicking on it with a mouse, by hitting ENTER or RETURN on the keyboard (if the button has the focus) or tapping by a finger.
An automated tool that helps find and fix specific problems on your computer.
The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a left arrow.

An e-mail security feature used to request confirmation that a message was received unaltered and information about who opened the message and when it was opened. This verification information is returned as a message to your Inbox.

The API platform, user interface, and Web service for delivering Windows updates and applications. Users can check for and install updates, view the update history for the computer, and turn on or change automatic updating settings. Windows Update can be used by consumers through the Windows Update Web service or by corporate customers who use Windows Server Update Services to control distribution within their organization.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
A scheme for uniquely identifying resources that may be available on the Internet by name, without regard to where they are located.
A scheme for uniquely identifying resources that may be available on the Internet by name, without regard to where they are located.
A detail about a file that helps identify it, such as a descriptive title, the author name, the subject, or a keyword that identifies topics or other important information in the file.
A Web hosting and Internet service provider who manages the Web server hardware and software required to make a Web site available on the Internet.
The window in which a user is currently working or directing input. An active window is typically at the top of the Z order and is distinguished by the color of its title bar.
A field data type that can contain up to 255 characters or the number of characters specified by the Fieldsize property, whichever is less.
A unit of measure referring to the height of a printed character. A point equals 1/72 of an inch, or approximately 1/28 of a centimeter.

The part of the Microsoft Office user interface above the main work area that presents commands and options to the user. The Ribbon replaced menus and toolbars starting in the 2007 Microsoft Office system.
A field data type that can contain up to 65,535 characters.
A window in an e-mail program where you can preview an item without opening it.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen or paper) is horizontal.
A number assigned to a specific inventory item to identify it and differentiate it from similar items with the same item number.

A period of time when a connection is active and communication can take place. For the purpose of data communication between functional units, session also refers to all the activities that take place during the establishment, maintenance, and release of the connection.
To pick a command or an option from within a graphical user interface, as by clicking a button in a dialog box or pulling down a menu and then releasing the mouse button on one of its options.
A unit of measure used in typesetting and desktop publishing, equal to one-twentieth of a printer's point, or 1/1440th of an inch.
A Web page editor command that inserts a horizontal line onto a Web page.
A tool that enables a user to sample the color of any pixel on a screen and apply that color to an object.

A page that contains the design and layout elements that you want to repeat on multiple pages in a publication. Using master pages for these common elements gives your publication a more consistent appearance.
A box with dotted borders in a slide layout that holds title and body text or objects such as charts, tables, and pictures.
To continue to press a keyboard key or mouse button.
A lightweight and task-specific add-in program that integrates with applications to expose data at a glance.
The amount of data that can be stored on a disk, usually measured in bytes.

A markup language for describing and exchanging structured data in a format that is independent of operating systems and applications. XML is a World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) specification and is a subset of Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML).
A line or row of characters used to lead the eye from a data label to a data point, or from a callout to the appropriate part of an illustration.
A line or row of characters used to lead the eye from a data label to a data point, or from a callout to the appropriate part of an illustration.
In a cascading style sheet style definition (or style rule), the HTML element linked to a particular set of style properties and values.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.
Usually used in statistical or scientific data, an error bar shows the potential error or degree of uncertainty relative to each data marker in a series.
An agreement in which a customer prepays for periodic or regular services.
An agreement in which a customer prepays for periodic or regular services.

An approach to restricting permission for a given document, workbook, presentation, or message. The policy defines which Office features are available, which information can be accessed, and what level of editing is allowed.
The , character.

A snapshot of information from an address book that has been downloaded so that an Outlook user can access it while disconnected from the server. It contains the properties of a user, such as e-mail addresses, that Outlook requires to send an e-mail message and display information about the sender.
A query that retrieves data stored on your intranet or the Internet.
A predefined or free-form figure — such as a line, oval, cube, flowchart symbol, banner, or free-form scribble — that the user can insert into a document and then customize.
The position of a point with reference to the x-axis, defined in conjunction with the y- and z-coordinates.
In computer graphics, a display method in which a viewing window on the screen scans horizontally or vertically, like a camera, to bring offscreen extensions of the current image smoothly into view.
In computer graphics, a display method in which a viewing window on the screen scans horizontally or vertically, like a camera, to bring offscreen extensions of the current image smoothly into view.

A common point of entry for spyware guarded by an agent. Examples of checkpoints include Startup Folder, dial up connections, Wi-Fi connections, Internet Safe Sites, Winsock Layered Service Providers, Windows Messenger Service, and SPAM Zombie prevention.
A numeric or string value that is not calculated and, therefore, does not change.
To enlarge a window to its largest size by double-clicking the title bar, clicking the Maximize button (at the right of the title bar), or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing X.
Pertaining to an operator that can hold an arbitrary number of arguments, or to a function that can hold an arbitrary number of operators.
Pertaining to an operator that can hold an arbitrary number of arguments, or to a function that can hold an arbitrary number of operators.
Capable of being retrieved (read), printed or copied but not changed (written) or saved.
An apartment that consists of one or more threads.
An apartment that consists of one or more threads.
Functions used to extract and display OLAP data (sets and values).
On a local area network (LAN), a drive that other computers on the network can connect to. A network drive allows people to access shared files and folders.
A data type consisting of a sequence of named values given in a particular order.

A hidden section of an e-mail message. From the time a message is first created, information about it is added to the message header, including technical details, such as who created the message and the software used to compose it.

A hidden section of an e-mail message. From the time a message is first created, information about it is added to the message header, including technical details, such as who created the message and the software used to compose it.
The title for a dialog that specifies how a signature line should be signed, including instructions for signers.
Having a frequency in the electromagnetic spectrum in the range just below that of red light.
A field defined in a query that displays the result of an expression rather than displaying stored data. The value is recalculated each time a value in the expression changes.
To create an object, such as an email message.
A client software component that declares a client's health state (by providing a statement of health) to a NAP agent.

The condition at a particular time of any of numerous elements of computing--a device, a communications channel, a network station, a program, a bit, or other element--used to report on or to control computer operations.

The condition at a particular time of any of numerous elements of computing--a device, a communications channel, a network station, a program, a bit, or other element--used to report on or to control computer operations.
An integrated proofing tool used to search on common words and display synonyms.
A control that appears dimmed on a form or data access page. A disabled control cannot get the focus and will not respond to mouse clicks.

A special visual or sound effect added to text or an object. For instance, a user can have the text bullet points fly in from the left, one word at a time, or hear the sounds of applause when a picture is uncovered.
The time for which a dry or alkaline cell is able to produce an electric current before it needs to be replaced.

Characterized by conversational exchange of input and output, as when a user enters a question or command and the system immediately responds. The interactivity of microcomputers is one of the features that makes them approachable and easy to use.
An exponentiation operator used in some programming languages. For example, the expression 3^2 represents the number 3 raised to the second power.

A link between a user's computer and a group of computers and other devices that enables the user to access printers, servers etc. The link can be through a wire, cable, phone line or wireless transmissions.
Pertaining to a product that can work with or is equivalent to another product.
The data transfer capacity, or speed of transmission, of a digital communications system as measured in bits per second (bps).
A key that accompanies a graphic and explains how information is presented.
A feature that enables users to provide input through the screen by using a finger or a pen.
To reverse playback of a digital media file at a speed that is faster than normal.
A function that takes a key, label, and seed as input, then produces an output of arbitrary length.

A character used to separate directory names in MS-DOS and UNIX path specifications. When used as a leading character, it means that the path specification begins from the topmost level for that disk drive.
In an environment capable of displaying multiple on-screen windows, the window containing the document that will be affected by current cursor movements, commands, and text entry.
To turn a computer off and back on again, either manually, or by clicking Restart.
A single position or item in a dimension. Dimension members can be user-defined or predefined and can have properties associated with them.
A Web-oriented technology developed by Microsoft that is designed to enable server-side scripting.
A row or column that uses a summary function to display the total of detail items in a PivotTable field.
The name of the control panel for Office (including the Tools Options dialog).
To copy files from a backup storage device to their normal location, especially if the files are being copied to replace files that were accidentally lost or deleted.

The visual experience of the premium Windows Vista editions. Windows Aero builds on the Basic and Standard user experiences to offer customers our best-designed, highest-performing desktop environment. A noticeable element of the new Windows Aero experience is the professional-looking, transparent glass design, which creates an open, lightweight environment but more importantly enables users to focus on their content rather than the interface.
A specified amount of processing performed as a unit by a computer.
An option that switches the view from the display of HTML source code to the display of Web page content.

E-mail accounts and folders that you can group and set common options for, such as whether to download headers or messages, size limits on downloaded messages, behavior online vs. offline, and time interval for connecting to the server.
Any graphics on a slide, including drawing objects, patterns in a background fill, and pictures.
A set of data that is organized and summarized into a multidimensional structure that is defined by a set of dimensions and measures.
A set of data that is organized and summarized into a multidimensional structure that is defined by a set of dimensions and measures.
A field that's assigned a column orientation in a PivotTable report. Items associated with a column field are displayed as column labels.

An upgrade option that allows users to upgrade from one edition of Windows to another by purchasing the upgrade online. It is enabled by Software Licensing Services (SLS) technology which allows a digital lincense to determine what features are enabled or disabled allowing Microsoft to sell either additional licenses or product upgrades through digital licenses (PUP-DL). Customers may either buy full packaged product (FPP) or upgrade quickly and conveniently electronically.
In database management, an identifier for a record or group of records in a datafile.
A number used to indicate the cost of a route in the Internet Protocol (IP) routing table that enables the selection of the best route among possible multiple routes to the same destination.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.

An unsolicited and typically unwelcome message, often commercial or political in nature, transmitted via the Internet as a mass mailing (sometimes as if from a fictitious user or domain) to a large number of recipients.
To perform an instruction.

A real-time conversation via computer using short instant messages between two or more participants. When a participant types a line of text and then presses the Enter key, that participant's words appear on the screens of the other participants, who can then respond in kind.
Pertaining to something that functions without external control.
The process of quitting all programs before closing the operating system.
A round chart that shows the size of items in a single data series, proportional to the sum of the items.
A dot, hyphen, or other character used to create a line that fills the space before a tab stop.
A server that hosts and delivers media across a network.
A computer monitor that supplements the main monitor.
The output created in desktop publishing applications.
A formalized instruction to a database to either return a set of records or perform a specified action on a set of records as specified in the query.

A downloadable Web application that helps Windows users identify which edition of Windows meets their needs, whether their PCs are ready for an upgrade to the next Windows version, and which features of the suggested Windows version will be able to run on their PCs.
A computer that stores email messages.
A computer that stores email messages.
A view of a document as it will appear in a Web browser. For example, the document appears as one long page (without page breaks) and text and tables wrap to fit in the window.
Data and the information needed to access that data from programs and databases that support the Open Database Connectivity (ODBC) protocol.
A long key occupying much of the bottom row of most keyboards that sends a space character to the computer.
The Internet protocol used to deliver information over the World Wide Web.
The Internet protocol used to deliver information over the World Wide Web.

In programming, a list of data values, all of the same type, any element of which can be referenced by an expression consisting of the array name followed by an indexing expression. Arrays are part of the fundamentals of data structures, which, in turn, are a major fundamental of computer programming.
To place information from storage into memory for processing, if it is data, or for execution, if it is program code.
The "digital persona" by which other users recognize and interact with you.
An instruction to a computer program that, when issued by the user, causes an action to be carried out. Commands are usually either typed at the keyboard or chosen from a menu.
The client software that enables users to connect to a remote computer that has the Remote Desktop feature enabled or to a remote desktop server.
A fixed-length data type with a maximum length of 8,000 bytes of binary data.
A diagram that is used to show steps toward a goal.
A special version of Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) that includes diagnostic, troubleshooting, and maintenance tools.
In some applications (especially databases), a structured window, box, or other self-contained element that serves as a visual filter for the underlying data it is presenting.
The first line of a paragraph printed by itself at the bottom of a page.
The first line of a paragraph printed by itself at the bottom of a page.
One mouse click (usually with the left mouse button).
A type of drop-down menu that appears when a user points to a command on a higher-level menu.
The process of ensuring that data meets specified criteria.
A user-friendly name displayed in place of a network location, e-mail address, contact name, or other, more formal name.
A range of cells that contains data and that is bounded by empty cells or worksheet borders.
A list of programs or tasks waiting for execution.
The ` character.
The ` character.
The field on a form in which the cursor or pointer is positioned.
An index file with two columns: the first column lists the text in the document that you want to index, and the second column lists the index entries to generate from the text in the first column.
To assign a drive letter, port, or computer name to a shared resource so that you can use it.
To automatically remove items to another folder periodically or delete them, based on the amount of time that they have been in the folder.
Possessing improved, advanced, or more sophisticated features.

A window that shows the design of these database objects - tables, queries, forms, reports, macros, and data access pages. In Design view, you can create new database objects and modify the design of existing ones.
An area of an application window that enables the user to navigate quickly to different parts of the program.
The process of inputting information.
An item in the Windows Control Panel that enables users to access Parental Controls and other third-party parental control features, such as web filters.
The ‐ character, used to break a word between syllables at the end of a line or to separate the parts of a compound word.

A file that contains the styles in a presentation, including the type and size of bullets and fonts; placeholder sizes and positions; background design and fill; color schemes; and a slide master and optional title master.
An item on the Control Panel that provides user a comprehensive view over all roamed content, as well as ability to check on the synchronization progress of individual items.
An animation enhancement that lets you apply effects to a diagram piece by piece; for example, from top to bottom of a pyramid diagram.
The time that a OneNote page was created.
A property of an object that can be quantified numerically.
An e-mail reply to a meeting request that indicates whether the sender will attend the meeting.
A device that puts text or images on paper or other print media.
A hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
A hardware-based security feature that prevents unauthorized access to a computer by providing full-volume encryption and integrity checking of boot components.
An application that contains a linked or embedded OLE object from another application.

A file system defined by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA) that is the successor to the CD-ROM file system (CDFS). UDF is used for removable disk media like DVD, CD, and magneto-optic (MO) disks.
A hardware device, or a logical partition of it, that reads data from and writes data to hard disks.
Pertaining to time on a schedule when a person may participate in a scheduled task.
A visual impairment that results in complete loss of vision in both eyes.
A character that is inserted in right-to-left and mixed text to specify the formatting of text when the inherent directionality of the text is insufficient to display expected results.
A sheet in a workbook that contains only a chart.

A collection of computers in a networked environment that share a common database, directory database, or tree. A domain is administered as a unit with common rules and procedures, which can include security policies, and each domain has a unique name.
The packaged Windows Media file that is created with Windows Media Rights Manager SDK.
A graphic element from the SmartArt feature.
Paragraph formatting in which the second and subsequent lines of a paragraph are indented more than the first line.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.
An area at the left side in some dialog boxes, such as Save As, Open, and Insert Picture that contains shortcuts to various folders.
A margin setting that adds extra space to the side or top margin of a document you plan to bind. A gutter margin ensures that text isn't obscured by the binding.

Content has been hashed and verified as valid against the signature. The certificate used to verify the signature is “valid” in the sense that it has a relationship to a trusted certificate authority (and isn’t expired, etc.)
A hard plastic disc on a mouse that is perpendicular to the mouse surface. It is normally located between the left and right mouse buttons and is used for scrolling.
A feature that allows the user to select from a gallery of pre-defined formatting styles and apply them quickly to tables, text, charts, drawing objects and SmartArt graphics.

A secure e-mail feature that lets you add sensitivity labels, such as Internal Use Only, to the message header. Security labels in your organization are controlled by security policies set up by your e-mail administrator.
A rectangle with sizing handles that surrounds a selected object or objects.
To position objects or text relative to some point, such as the page margin.
Pertaining to a file format that allows for VBA code. Examples of file extensions for macro-enabled formats are .docm, .pptm, .xlsm.
A dialog box that displays one complete record at a time. You can use data forms to add, change, locate, and delete records.
In Windows Media Player, a database that contains information about digital media files on a computer, a network drive, or the Internet.
One or more rows of cells commonly used to display numbers and other items for quick reference and analysis. Items in a table are organized into rows and columns.

The cell in which each input value from a data table is substituted. Any cell on a worksheet can be the input cell. Although the input cell does not need to be part of the data table, the formulas in data tables must refer to the input cell.
One character (or more) printed slightly below the baseline of surrounding text.

The core component of the Excel Server that includes the full Excel calculation functionality. It loads and saves Excel workbooks, queries and refreshes external data, calculates workbooks, and provides the calculated results to the caller.
In the context of processes or tasks that are part of an operating system or program, operating without interaction with the user while the user is working on another task.
To advance audio or video playback at a speed that is faster than normal.

A technique used to trick computer users into revealing personal or financial information. A common online phishing scam starts with an e-mail message that appears to come from a trusted source but actually directs recipients to provide information to a fraudulent Web site.
An item provided and signed by the DCE security server that is both a proof of identity and a list of group memberships.
A column chart subtype that compares values across categories. The categories are organized horizontally, and values vertically, to emphasize variation over time.
A column chart subtype that compares the percentage that each value contributes to a total across categories.
A column chart subtype that compares data points along two axes.
A variation on a column chart that uses cylinder shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A variation on a column chart that uses cone shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A variation on a column chart that uses pyramid shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A stacked column chart that creates the effect of floating columns by making the first data series invisible. The result is a chart that depicts mininum and maximum values.
A bar chart subtype that compares the percentage that each value contributes to a total across categories.
A variation on a bar chart that uses cone shapes instead of horizontal rectangles.
A variation on a bar chart that uses pyramid shapes instead of horizontal rectangles.
A variation on a bar chart that uses cylinder shapes instead of horizontal rectangles.
A customizable extension to Microsoft Office Outlook forms.
A bar chart subtype that compares values across categories.
A pie chart with user-defined values extracted and combined into a second pie.
A pie chart with user-defined values extracted and combined into a stacked bar.
A pie chart that displays the contribution of each value to a total while emphasizing individual values, by showing each slice of the pie as "pulled out," or separate, from the whole.
A chart that plots numerical data along two value axes (x,y).
A chart that plots numerical data along two value axes (x,y).
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
A chart that shows a three dimensional surface that connects a set of data points. As in a topographic map, colors and patterns indicate areas that are in the same range of values.
A surface chart subtype that provides a view of the surface chart from above, with colors representing specific ranges of values.
A contour chart displayed without color.
A chart that displays data in rings, where each ring represents a data series.
A doughnut chart that displays the contribution of each value to a total while emphasizing individual values, by showing each slice of the doughnut as "pulled out," or separate, from the whole.
A best-fit curved trendline that is used when the rate of change in the data increases or decreases quickly and then levels out.
A curved trendline that is used when data fluctuates.
A curved trendline that is used with data sets that compare measurements that increase at a specific rate.
A curved trendline that is used when data values rise or fall at constantly increasing rates.
A trendline that smoothes out fluctuations in data to show a pattern or trend more clearly.
To ensure that all data sources that are used by a KPI or scorecard are available.
A service or feature that renders the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. These captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
A numeric or other designation appended to a product name to identify a particular release.
A UI element that provides access to online Help or other forms of user assistance.
An effect applied to a graphical object that typically reduces the difference between the outline of the object and the graphical area next to it.
Software that provides encryption for sensitive data, such as passwords, in applications.
The round button in the lower left-hand corner of the Windows screen that allows the user to click and display the Start menu.
A Microsoft site that provides a comprehensive listing of updates that can be distributed over a corporate network.

A feature of Remote Desktop Services that enables the user to access a program remotely through Remote Desktop Services but have it appear as if it is running on the user's local computer. Users can run RemoteApp programs side by side with their local programs.

The Microsoft implementation of an integrity level. In particular, a protection level, refers to an integrity label that contains only level information, without the additonal information traditionally contained within integrity level.
The date when a project or task is scheduled to begin.

A unique view for displaying appointments, tasks, and other information in the form of a Web page. You can customize the Outlook Today page for your organization, or for individuals or groups within your organization, to display the information most relevant to them.
To take out objects from a list, database, or other item, or to uninstall a program.
To set an entity, such as a feature, configuration, or object, back to its defaults.
To locate text or a specific item on a Web page or in a document.
A navigation button used to complete and close a wizard.
A group of reusable settings that describes the shared attributes and behaviors of a list item, a document, or a folder.
Stored on a server or client computer that is configured to control access to content by using information rights management (IRM) technology.
A feature that tracks and stores a record of a shared document when it is first created, and each time it is edited.
The folder where junk e-mail is delivered.
The expected total cost of a task or project, based on performance as of the status date. EAC is calculated as follows: EAC = ACWP + (BAC-BCWP)/CPI.
A format used by the Bentley MicroStation CAD program to store drawing files.
The original project, resource, and assignment cost as shown in the baseline plan. The baseline cost is a snapshot of the cost at the time when the baseline plan was saved.
To briefly press a UI element with your fingertip or stylus to perform an activity (such as choosing an action from a menu or opening an item).
A number from 0 to 1 that reveals how closely the estimated values for the trendline correspond to your actual data. A trendline is most reliable when its R-squared value is at or near 1.
A number from 0 to 1 that reveals how closely the estimated values for the trendline correspond to your actual data. A trendline is most reliable when its R-squared value is at or near 1.

The difference between the budgeted cost of work performed [BCWP] and the budgeted cost of work scheduled [BCWS]. This is calculated as follows: SV = Budgeted Cost of Work Performed - Budgeted Cost of Work Scheduled.
A label that identifies the categories, values, or series in a chart.
A label that identifies the categories, values, or series in a chart.
A small line of measurement, similar to a division on a ruler, that intersects an axis.
The developer of a macro that is trusted by you on your computer. The trusted publisher is identified by the certificate that they used to digitally sign the macro.
The developer of a macro that is trusted by you on your computer. The trusted publisher is identified by the certificate that they used to digitally sign the macro.
The formatting attributes that are available by default in an application's style list.
A Project view that displays a project's tasks in a calendar format.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.

A code that credit card companies use to authorize credit card charges. For example, American Express uses a four-digit number on the front of the credit card, and Visa, MasterCard, and Discover use a three-digit number on the back.
A chart axis that represents the category for each data point. It displays arbitrary text values like Qtr1, Qtr2, and Qtr3; it cannot display scaled numerical values.
A field that is displayed in the category area of PivotChart view. Items in a category field appear as labels on the category axis.
A way to see if a certificate used to sign a message is valid. Outlook can check the status of the certificate from the issuing certification authority's database.
In Visual Basic for Applications, the window that is used to display, edit, and write module-level and procedure code.

A keyword or phrase with an associated color that helps you keep track of items, such as messages, contacts, and appointments. You can use color categories to easily find, sort, filter, or group items.
The part of PivotTable view that contains column fields.
A format, such as cell shading or font color, that Excel automatically applies to cells if a specified condition is true.
A view of an individual contact that contains all the information stored in the contact.

A set of buttons used to move through contact items displayed in Address Cards or Detailed Address Cards view. The Contact index moves the focus to the first contact whose name begins with the selected character.
The shape of how scheduled work for an assignment is distributed across time. Use a contour to control how Project schedules the work of a resource.
A programming interface to access and manipulate database objects.
The area of the window that displays the result set of your query.
In the Charts And Graphs template, a control handle on the Line Graph shape that you can drag to change the values in the graph.
A character that is used to separate the day, month, and year when date values are formatted. The characters are determined by system settings or by the Format function.
The font that a program uses by default to display text.

The amount of time between the scheduled start of a task and the time when work should actually begin on the task; it is often used to resolve resource overallocations. There are two types of delay: assignment delay and leveling delay.
A remark or topic of discussion that is associated with a Web page or Microsoft Office file and is stored on a discussion server.
A picture that is stored within a document rather than being linked to a source file outside of the document.
An address similar to a URL that provides network access to an event, such as a live broadcast. Attendees go to this address to view the event from their computers.
An element of an expression that refers to the value of a field, control, or property.
Data that is stored outside of the application that is currently in use.
A range of data that is brought into a worksheet but that originates outside of Excel, such as in a database or text file.

termGrp.term: rainse dàta air an taobh a-muigh

descripGrp.descrip: A pane located on top of the Navigation Pane that has copies of your Inbox, Sent Items, and so on. You can add, remove, and arrange folders in this pane. Collapse or expand the pane by clicking the arrow in the Favorite Folders header.

A button that identifies a field in a PivotTable or PivotChart report. You can drag the field buttons to change the layout of the report, or click the arrows next to the buttons to change the level of detail displayed in the report.
The part of PivotTable or PivotChart view that contains filter fields.
A field in the filter area that you can use to filter data displayed in PivotTable or PivotChart view. Filter fields perform the same functions as page fields in Microsoft Excel PivotTable reports.

An Internet Web page or intranet page that is associated with an Outlook folder. If a page has been associated with the folder and the option is set, the Web page appears in the Outlook window whenever you select the folder.
A location on a computer's hard drive to store a local copy of a form to improve performance when opening a form subsequent times.

A method to find a specific value for a cell by adjusting the value of one other cell. When goal seeking, Excel varies the value in a cell that you specify until a formula that's dependent on that cell returns the result you want.
A rank or category assigned to a material resource that denotes functional use but not level of quality. A low-grade resource is not necessarily a low-quality resource.
A phone number format for dialing any call from any location or with a calling card.

The special characters used to extend the joiner between two Arabic characters. Used to improve the appearance of justified text by visually lengthening words rather than increasing the spacing between words. Can also function like a hyphen.
Resolving resource conflicts or overallocations by delaying or splitting certain tasks. When Project levels a resource, its selected assignments are distributed and rescheduled.
A type of cascading style sheet that exists in a separate file and is referenced throughout one or more Web pages.
A character, usually a comma or semicolon, that separates elements in a list.
A calendar that is based on cycles of the moon phase.
A range in an XML list that has been linked to an element in an XML map.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings. When you drag a shape from a stencil onto the drawing page, the shape becomes an instance of that master.
A tone in a picture that is in the middle of the tonal range, between the lightest and darkest tones
A character that does not have strong right-to-left or left-to-right language attributes.

A file you create on your hard disk or a network share to store OLAP source data for a PivotTable or PivotChart report. Offline cube files allow you to keep working when you are not connected to the OLAP server.

Principles that guide developers as they assign responsibilities to software classes and design system behavior. They are most useful when creating collaboration diagrams where messages imply responsibility.
A field that you use to enter or display how much of a task has been completed. This value is expressed as the percentage of the task duration that has been completed.
A schedule of task start and finish dates and resource and cost data.
A list of projects within an organization that may share common management of scope, budget, or resources.
Placing elements, such as text and graphics, on a page to let the page author control the exact location and layer order of a page element.
A bookmark that Microsoft Word automatically sets in each document. For example, the \Sel predefined bookmark refers to the current selection or the insertion point.
The degree of excellence, or the desired standards, in a product, process, or project.
A default color category that is assigned to an item when you click the Categories column for the item in your Inbox or other table view. You set this color category from the Categorize menu.
To move a task to a lower outline level [to the right] in the Task Name field. When you indent a task, it becomes a subtask of the nearest preceding task at a higher outline level.
A task that occurs repeatedly during the course of a project. For example, you might define the weekly status meeting as a recurring task.

An Excel template (.xlt file) that includes one or more queries or PivotTable reports that are based on external data. When you save a report template, Excel saves the query definition but doesn't store the queried data in the template.
A certificate that has been cancelled by a certificate authority (CA) and is no longer valid.
A representation of the communication path between actors.

A default flag that is assigned to an item when you click the Flag Status column in your Inbox or other table view. You set the default time, date, or other criteria for the flag from the Follow Up menu.
An actor's interface component through which actors communicate with other actors.
Any one-dimensional (1-D) shape that can be glued between two shapes in a drawing to connect the shapes.
The part of PivotTable view that contains row fields.
The numbered gray area to the left of each row.
An accessibility aid for people who are blind or have learning disabilities, such as dyslexia. These aids make on-screen information available as synthesized speech or a refreshable Braille display.
A field that is displayed in the series area of a chart and that contains series items. A series is a group of related data points.
A cell that has been linked to a non-repeating element in an XML map.
To change the dimensions of a shape by dragging one of its handles after it has been selected with the pointer tool.
A small overlap that extends the shape of the upper of two differently colored, abutting objects. A spread extends beyond the area that it knocks out.

A Microsoft Office Web Component that provides the interactive functionality of a spreadsheet on a Web page. You can enter data, add formulas and functions, apply filters, change formatting, and recalculate.
The default text font for worksheets. The standard font determines the default font for the Normal cell style.
A date that you set [rather than the current date] for reporting the time, cost, or performance condition of a project.

In an activity diagram, a way of assigning responsibility to action states. Swimlanes are columns with solid vertical lines on each side. Each swimlane represents the responsible class, person, or organizational unit.
Any application or process that you want to model. Examples of systems include a computer game, a process for assembling microchips, and a library information system.
One of a set of major and minor fonts that is applied to a file. Theme fonts, theme colors, and theme effects compose a theme.
A type of pane that presents the current scanned document as one or more small images.

The time period indicator at the top of the Gantt views, the Resource Graph view, the Task Usage view, and the Resource Usage view. You can customize it to show up to three tiers that can display various time units: top, middle, and bottom.
A special row in a list or table that provides a selection of aggregate functions useful for working with numerical data.

An arrow that shows the relationship between the active cell and its related cells. Tracer arrows are blue when pointing from a cell that provides data to another cell, and red if a cell contains an error value, such as #DIV/0!.
Optional text for a trendline, including either the regression equation or the R-squared value, or both. A trendline label can be formatted and moved; it cannot be sized.

A folder or file path on your computer or a location on your intranet from which it is safe to run code. Default trusted locations include the Templates, Addins, and Startup folders, and you can specify your own trusted locations.

A list of software publisher certificates used to digitally sign code, such as macros. Because you explicitly trust the software publishers, their code is allowed to run on your computer without needing to prompt for permission.

The quantity of a resource assigned to a task. The maximum units is the maximum number of units available for the resource. For example, if you have three plumbers, the maximum units is 300 percent or three plumbers working full-time.
In line charts with multiple data series, bars that indicate the difference between data points in the first and last series.
A chart axis that displays scaled numerical values.
A bar displayed along the left side of a document window. You can use the vertical ruler to adjust the top and bottom page margins and the row height in tables.
A calendar in widespread use. It was introduced in 1582 A.D. as a revision to the Julian calendar.
An XML structure that consists of a start tag, an end tag, and the information between the tags. Elements can have attributes and can contain other elements.
A switch (\#) or instruction that specifies how Microsoft Word will display the numeric result of a field.
A switch (\*) or instruction that specifies the capitalization, numeral style, and character formatting that Microsoft Word uses in a field result.
Pertaining to information that shows what has actually occurred. For example, the actual start date for a task is the day that the task actually started.
The percentage of a resource's capacity that is designated for a specific assignment.
An allowed path from one state to another.
The number of levels that a task is indented from the top level of the outline. You can indent tasks up to 65,000 levels in Project.
Resource cost per hour. Project includes two types of pay rates: standard rates and overtime rates.
A group of related tasks that completes a major step in a project.
Conditions you specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query or filter.
A diagram that shows dependencies between project tasks. Tasks are represented by boxes, or nodes, and task dependencies are represented by lines that connect the boxes.
Text that you enter by using a keyboard or that your Tablet PC converts from handwriting or speech.

An external reference, such as a graphic image, linked to an external Web server that is placed in an HTML-formatted message. It can be used to verify that your e-mail address is valid when the message is opened and images downloaded.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
A tool that enables a user to get another user's attention by shaking the user's conversation window and playing a sound.
An animated greeting a customer can send to a contact.
To package your publication files by using the Pack and Go Wizard.
A person who is not required to attend a meeting.
An initial value used to generate pseudorandom numbers.
The ability of one element to see or refer to another. For one element to send a message to another element, the latter must be visible to the former.
The primary address that is used in mail merges.
An effect that applies a halo of color around the perimeter of an object.
To display an object.
A file that stores an image as graphical objects (lines, circles, polygons) rather than as pixels. Metafiles preserve an image more accurately than pixels when the image is resized.
A page that you can assign to another page to create multiple layers in a drawing.
The size of the finished page of a printed publication, after trimming.
The size of the sheet of paper on which you print the publication, before trimming.
A word or string of characters in a formula that represents a cell, range of cells, formula, or constant value.
A name for an Excel table, which is a collection of data about a particular subject that is stored in records (rows) and fields (columns).
A display mode that shows as much content as possible by hiding elements such as navigation and toolbars.

When a ribbon is divided into multiple views, any one of the views. Every tab contains functionally related commands and other controls that are organized in groups. Typically, ribbon tabs are labeled.
An effect that applies to the exterior border around each character of your text or shape.
An effect that applies to the appearance of the interior of an enclosed text character or other shape.
A file that contains the data that a program will process and store in a destination file.
The distance between the camera’s lens and the image plane.
A feature that identifies elements in your file that aren't supported or will behave differently in a different format or previous version of the product.
A UI element the user presses to agree to an incoming file transfer, invitation, audio/video call, or application sharing.
To accept an incoming telephone call.
To execute a program.
A picture made by combining a series of photos into one large picture to provide a complete view of an area or location that cannot fit in a single shot.
A collection of communications (e-mail, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.

Extra information displayed to a user while they are composing an e-mail message. MailTips are displayed in an InfoBar, similar to the banner that appears saying "This message has not been sent." MailTips reveal anything that might be unexpected about the delivery or audience of the message, such as recipient validity or Out of Office status or whether the message might not be delivered.

A collection of shapes arranged in a tree structure that helps analyze and summarize data in a visual, easy-to-understand format. It starts out as a single shape, called a top node, that contains information imported from a worksheet, table, view, or cube.
A policy that specifies the length of time during which data, documents, and other records must be available for recovery.
A sequence of data such as numbers, number and text combinations, dates, or time periods, based on an established pattern and used to automatically fill data into worksheet cells.
A communication technology based on short range (4cm or less) wireless data exchange.
The window that displays solutions, projects, and files, as well as access to the commands that pertain to them.
A drop-down button that performs a default action and can also expand to a list of other possible actions.
The information provided with a product by a manufacturer describing how to use a product.
To tap a device screen and hold one's finger or stylus in place.
A program that extends the capabilities of Internet Explorer.

A collection of visual elements and sounds for your computer desktop or device User Interface. A theme determines the look of the various visual elements of your User Interface, such as windows, icons, fonts, and colors, and it can include sounds.

An Internet Explorer feature that allows users to surf the Web without leaving a browsing history, cookies or other information on the PC so they can do online banking on a shared computer, for example.
An intelligent spam-filtering solution integrated across all Microsoft e-mail platforms.
A service for wireless products that allows users to send and receive brief messages consisting of text and numbers to and from mobile phones and devices.

A virtual community that provides people with opportunities to interact (via blogs, chats, newsgroups, webcasts, user groups, and forums) with Microsoft employees, experts, and peers in order to share knowledge and news about Microsoft technology.
An alert that is set by the user to be activated at a particular time.
A renamed .cab file which contains a .theme file, and optionally one or more desktop backgrounds, icons, mouse pointer files, and sound files. It does not contain executables or screen savers.
A folder that stores the user's graphics, e.g. digital pictures. Many graphic design and photo-editing programs use this location by default to open or save graphic files.
A button that replaces the File menu beginning with some 2007 Microsoft Office system programs.
A button that replaces the File menu beginning with some 2007 Microsoft Office system programs.

An option on the Views menu in Windows Explorer that shows the most appropriate details for the file type in a flexible layout rather than only showing the details associated with the column headers in the view.

A comprehensive PC maintenance center that provides the user with a single point of entry for tasks and notifications associated with PC Health, i.e. security, diagnostics, problem reports and solutions, how to update the system (Windows Updates), performance, reliability, backup and restore, and complete PC backup (recovery and Rescue my PC).

A gallery that allows users to create a quick rule to move mail to a selected folder based on the sender, recipients, or conversation of the currently selected e-mail message without opening the full Create Rule dialog.
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
A password that helps prevent unauthorized access to homegroup files and printers.
An action that removes redundant messages from an e-mail conversation to reduce information overload and improve readability.
A fork within a conversation, where more than one reply was made to a single e-mail and caused a split in the conversation.
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
A feature that replicates formatting from a source item — such as text in Word, a cell in Excel, a control in Access, or a shape in Publisher — to one or more target items.
A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone else’s computer.
To fix an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, in a given area of the UI, so it is always accessible in that area (e.g., to make a library always visible in the navigation pane).
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area (e.g. to make a library non-visible in the navigation pane).
To locate or come upon through action.
A pencil tool that works with texture and simulates a real life pencil in stroke.
A Windows feature that enables users to easily roll back their PC to an earlier good state while keeping their data safe.
A process by which multiple authors edit a shared document simultaneously, or collaborate effectively even when they are not online at the same time.
A feature that provides access to gallery of frequently-used actions with the touch of a button. Users can customize the gallery to execute a combination of operations in one click.
A frame that contains text, shapes, pictures, or other content. A slide is a digital equivalent to a traditional film slide.
To mark an e-mail conversation so that all current and future messages in the conversation are automatically moved to the Deleted Items folder.
A special control that shows pictures, names and titles of people who are attending a meeting, or who are the recipients of an e-mail message.

termGrp.term: liosta nan daoine a bhios an làthair/a gheibh e

descripGrp.descrip: A user's work day hours as specified in Microsoft Office Outlook by the day of the week and the start and end times.
The auto-reply text specified using Outlook's Automatic Replies or Out of Office Assistant.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A tool used to turn on language-specific options for the languages one wants to use with a product.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, e-mail address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.

A handler that displays a lightweight, read-only preview of a file’s contents without launching the application associated with the file. For example, a preview handler displays a Shell item in the Windows Explorer preview pane.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.
An item on the user's Status menu. A user can select this status to indicate that they are not actively using their computer.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a hierarchical structure, such as an organization chart, or a decision tree.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to illustrate connections.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show how parts relate to a whole.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show proportional relationships with the largest component on the top or bottom.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
A feature that replicates the animation associated with a source object to one or more target objects.
An abstract grouping of similar animation effects.
An effect that a user can apply to an image to achieve a specific artistic look.
A visual representation of an audio signal over time.
An image editing feature that allows a user to isolate the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
An option that removes narrations and laser pointer gestures or timings from a presentation or from a specific slide.
A set of cryptographic algorithms specified by the US National Security Agency to provide an interoperable standard for government and industry.
The portion of InfoPath used to design forms.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
A security feature that validates files before allowing them to be loaded by the application, in order to protect against file format vulnerabilities.

A feature that allows the user to superimpose a dot over a presentation and control its position with the mouse. The appearance of the dot is similar to that of a traditional laser pointer, and it is broadcast to all presentation viewers and can be recorded into video (Save to Video).
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
An option that initiates an e-mail response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that makes Outlook auto-complete lists available through the default Exchange mailbox.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A feature that makes automatic versions of user documents during each autosave operation and allows the user to revert to previous copies of the document with ease.
A feature that alerts users to potential issues with e-mail recipients before the message is sent.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A feature that displays a definition or translation of a word or piece of text in a ScreenTip when the pointer is moved over the selection.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
An abstract grouping of similar transition effects.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.
A feature that helps users of some Office applications to improve the accessibility of documents they create.
An instant message that is transmitted while the sender or recipient is offline.
The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.

termGrp.term: Cuidiche Windows Live airson clàradh a-steach

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that offers improved security by loading a document in a read-only view, rather than in the full editor, for scenarios that pose a greater potential security risk.
A package containing everything you need to show one or many PowerPoint presentations on another computer. This package can be saved to a folder or burned to a CD.

A feature that allows the user to indicate that a document is trusted, and therefore can be opened without security notifications, so long as the filepath and creation time of the document remain unchanged.
A list that displays someone's recent activity on Windows Live.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The link to the main landing/start page on Windows Live.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
A feature that allows you to preview the appearance of a formatting option or command before actually applying it to selected text or objects.
A Windows feature that provides a direct connection to a corporate network for people working outside of the office. It is a superior alternative to VPN.
A PC (desktop and beyond) search platform that allows search of the local hard drive plus network locations like SharePoint sites and the Internet.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.
To break a connection.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression, a timeline, or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works well for illustrating both Level 1 and Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Emphasizes the interaction or relationships among the groups of information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show either related or contrasting concepts with some connection, such as opposing forces. The first two lines of Level 1 text are used for text in the arrows. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression; a timeline; sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow; or to emphasize movement or direction. Level 1 text appears inside an arrow shape while Level 2 text appears below the arrow shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the stages or steps rather than the connecting arrows or flow. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship of components to a whole in quadrants. The first four lines of Level 1 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show how individual parts form a whole. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond to the evenly distributed wedge or pie shapes. The top Level 1 text shape appears outside of the rest of the pie for emphasis. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, interconnected, or hierarchical relationships with the largest component on the bottom and narrowing up. Level 1 text appears in the pyramid segments and Level 2 text appears in shapes alongside each segment.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape, and its Level 2 text corresponds to the surrounding circular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment, gradations, or hierarchical relationships. The first five lines of Level 1 text are associated with a circle. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to show timeline information. Works well with both Level 1 and Level 2 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping or interconnected relationships. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond with a circle. If there are four or fewer lines of Level 1 text, the text is inside the circles. If there are more than four lines of Level 1 text, the text is outside of the circles. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small circular shapes are designed to contain pictures. Works well for illustrating both Level 1 and Level 2 text. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.

termGrp.term: liosta lùbte le dealbhan a chum cuideim

descripGrp.descrip: A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the stages or steps rather than the connecting arrows or flow.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression through several processes that make up an overall workflow. Also works for illustrating contrasting processes. The Level 1 text corresponds to the first arrow shape on the left, while the Level 2 text corresponds to horizontal sub-steps for each shape that contains Level 1 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a long or non-linear sequence or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with Level 1 text only. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression, a timeline, or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to emphasize movement or direction. Can be used to emphasize information in the starting shape. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a timeline or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with Level 1 text because each line of Level 1 text appears inside the arrow shape. Level 2 text appears outside the arrow shape.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works best with minimal Level 1 and Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the connection between all components. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of interconnected information. The circular shapes are designed to contain pictures.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show ideas or concepts that converge to a central point. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships of concepts or components to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central circular shape and the lines of Level 2 text correspond to the surrounding rectangular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show two opposing ideas or concepts. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to an arrow and works well with Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea in a cyclical progression. Each of the first four lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a wedge or pie shape, and Level 2 text appears in a rectangular shape to the side of the wedge or pie shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used with large amounts of Level 2 text to show a progression through stages.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show ideas or concepts that progress outward from a central source. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships to a central idea in a cycle. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the central circular shape. Emphasizes the surrounding circles rather than the central idea. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the equals sign (=).Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the filtering of information or how parts merge into a whole. Emphasizes the final outcome. Can contain up to four lines of Level 1 text; the last of these four Level 1 text lines appears below the funnel and the other lines correspond to a circular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show interlocking ideas. Each of the first three lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a gear shape, and their corresponding Level 2 text appears in rectangles next to the gear shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the placement of concepts along two axes. Emphasizes the individual components rather than the whole. The first four lines of Level 1 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups and sub-groups of information, or steps and sub-steps in a task, process, or workflow.
