Level 1 text corresponds to the top-level horizontal shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to vertical sub-steps under each related top-level shape. Works well for emphasizing sub-groups or sub-steps, hierarchical information, or multiple lists of information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing from top to bottom.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing across groups. Can also be used to group or list information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped lists of information. Works well with large amounts of text. All text has the same level of emphasis, and direction is not implied.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing horizontally. Works well for decision trees.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped information with an emphasis on related pictures. The top shapes are designed to contain pictures.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing horizontally and grouped hierarchically. Emphasizes heading or level 1 text. The first line of Level 1 text appears in the shape at the beginning of the hierarchy, and the second and all subsequent lines of Level 1 text appear at the top of the tall rectangles.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, or interconnected, or hierarchical relationships with the largest component on the top and narrowing down. Level 1 text appears in the pyramid segments and Level 2 text appears in shapes alongside each segment.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical relationships progressing from top to bottom and grouped hierarchically. Emphasizes heading or level 1 text. The first line of Level 1 text appears in the shape at the beginning of the hierarchy, and all subsequent lines of Level 1 text appear to the left of the tall rectangles.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping relationships in a sequence. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events that can occur in any direction.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment relationships. Each of the first three lines of Level 1 text correspond to the upper left text in the shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to the smaller shapes. Works best with minimal Level 2 lines of text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Each shape has the same level of importance. Works well when direction does not need to be indicated.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show two opposing ideas, or ideas that diverge from a central point. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to an arrow. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show hierarchical information or reporting relationships in an organization. The assistant shape and the Org Chart hanging layouts are available with this layout.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information. The small shapes on the upper corners are designed to contain pictures. Emphasizes Level 2 text over Level 1 text, and is a good choice for large amounts of Level 2 text.

termGrp.term: liosta de dhealbhan a chum cuideim

descripGrp.descrip: A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. The rectangular shapes in the background are designed to contain pictures.

termGrp.term: pròiseas le dealbhan a chum cuideim

descripGrp.descrip: A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The top shapes are designed to contain pictures and pictures are emphasized over text. Works well for pictures with short text captions.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show information illustrating a process or workflow. Level 1 text appears in the circular shapes and Level 2 text appears in the arrow shapes. Works best for minimal text and to emphasize movement or direction.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show multiple groups of information or steps and sub-steps in a task, process, or workflow. Level 1 text corresponds to the top horizontal shapes, and Level 2 text corresponds to vertical sub-steps under each related top-level shape.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show proportional, interconnected, or hierarchical relationships. Text appears in the rectangular shapes on top of the pyramid background

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationship to a central idea. Emphasizes both information in the center circle and how information in the outer ring of circles contributes to the central idea. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the central circle, and its Level 2 text corresponds to the outer ring of circles. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show relationships to a central idea in a cycle. The center shape can contain a picture. Level 1 text appears in the smaller circles and any related Level 2 text appears to the side of the smaller circles.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show both overlapping relationships and the relationship to a central idea in a cycle. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape and the lines of Level 2 text correspond to the surrounding circular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes. Does not emphasize directionality.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or a sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the interconnected pieces. Each of the first seven lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a wedge or pie shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Emphasizes Level 2 text, since each line appears in a separate shape.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show containment, proportional, or interconnected relationships. The first nine lines of Level 1 text appear in the triangular shapes. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Circular shapes contain Level 1 text, and the corresponding rectangles contain Level 2 text. Works well for numerous details and minimal Level 1 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a downward progression through stages. Each of the first five lines of Level 1 text corresponds with a rectangle. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information built from top to bottom, and the hierarchies within each group. This layout does not contain connecting lines.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the top shape and its Level 2 text is used for the subsequent lists.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show interrelated or overlapping information. Each of the first seven lines of Level 1 text appears in the rectangular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts. Works well with both Level 1 and Level 2 text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to represent a continuing sequence of stages, tasks, or events in a circular flow. Emphasizes the arrows or flow rather than the stages or steps. Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show the relationships of four quadrants to a whole. The first line of Level 1 text corresponds to the central shape, and the first four lines of Level 2 text appear in the quadrants. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. Works well with large amounts of text.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or steps that trend upward in a task, process, or workflow. Each of the first five lines of Level 1 text corresponds to a point on the arrow. Works best with minimal text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow that move toward a common goal. Works well for bulleted lists of information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow. Maximizes both horizontal and vertical display space for shapes. Places more emphasis on the interrelationships among the shapes than on direction or movement.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show groups of information or steps in a task, process, or workflow. Works well with large amounts of Level 2 text. A good choice for text with a main point and multiple sub-points.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show several groups of information, especially groups with large amounts of Level 2 text. A good choice for bulleted lists of information.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. Works well for lists with long headings or top-level information.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow, or to emphasize movement or direction. Emphasizes Level 2 text over Level 1 text, and is a good choice for large amounts of Level 2 text.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the arrow. Works best with Level 1 text only.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small circles are designed to contain pictures.

termGrp.term: liosta inghearach le dealbhan a chum cuideim

descripGrp.descrip: A SmartArt graphic layout used to show non-sequential or grouped blocks of information. The small shapes on the left are designed to contain pictures.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show a progression or sequential steps in a task, process, or workflow from top to bottom. Works best with Level 1 text, since the vertical space is limited.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show overlapping relationships. A good choice for emphasizing growth or gradation. Works best with Level 1 text only. The first seven lines of Level 1 text correspond to a circular shape. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A formula giving the roots of a quadratic equation.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.
A type of personal identification number (PIN) for the SIM card, consisting of 4 digits, that is used to gain access to your mobile phone.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
A category of sensor that may use all or some of the following applied stimulus to detect movement: ultrasound, infrared, heat and vibration.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A category of sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
An Internet site that provides a collection of products and services developed by Microsoft partners for Microsoft Office users.
A view mode in Internet Explorer that determines whether content is rendered as if users were viewing it in a previous version of Internet Explorer.
An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 802.11 wireless network in which Service Set Identifier (SSID) suppression is enabled.

A feature that prevents Internet Explorer from storing data about your browsing session. This helps prevent anyone else who might be using your computer from seeing where you visited and what you looked at on the Web.
The feature that blocks third-party web content that could potentially track someone's web activity.
The Windows Live service for event planning and invitations.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.
To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.
A feature that allows the user to digitally alter a picture to increase or decrease the sharpness of focus.
A zoom out gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving towards the other finger at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A zoom-in gesture represented by two fingers with at least one of them moving away from each other at any angle, within an acceptable tolerance.
A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A gallery containing thumbnail views of open application windows.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
A streaming technology that quickly installis Office over the Internet, internal networks, local file systems, or from offline media.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).

A COM-based multimedia platform and infrastructure for digital media in Microsoft Windows. It focuses on content protection, audio and video quality, and interoperability for digital rights management (DRM).
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.

A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A Web site from Microsoft which provides solutions for the top issues about Windows Update or Microsoft Update, and enables you to contact a support professional.
A feature that provides one-click filtering controls that make it easy to narrow down the portion of a data set that's being looked at.
A miniature chart that can be inserted into text or embedded within a cell on a worksheet to illustrate highs, lows, and trends in your data.
An Outlook Calendar view in which each calendar is listed vertically (not side-by-side). This view is optimized for viewing a schedule for a group and scheduling a meeting for a group.
A feature that converts each slide in a presentation into a single image and rebuilds a new, compressed PPT presentation that can easily be shared, but not edited.
A viewer that allows users to display Excel workbooks on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey important data or charts and illustrations.
A viewer that allows users to display Word documents on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to convey text and images on a small screen.

A feature that automates the task of positioning images and combining them with text in documents. It produces attractive, editable designs that highlight photos and accompanying text and make it easy for novices to produce compelling, high quality photo layouts.

A feature that automates the task of positioning images and combining them with text in documents. It produces attractive, editable designs that highlight photos and accompanying text and make it easy for novices to produce compelling, high quality photo layouts.
A numeric keypad that is part of a device, is displayed on a device, or is in a computer program that you use to enter information in the context of a phone call.

An icon that is attached to an event and that is viewable in someone's calendar. Depending on the calendar view, a charm may appear next to an event title, or may be the only visual representation of an event on a calendar day.
A traditional graphics plotter that uses pens to draw on paper. Pen plotters use one or more colored pens, either fiber-tipped pens or, for highest-quality output, drafting pens.
A view that shows all of the resources on a project and their work over time. This makes it easy to rearrange work, schedule new work, and manage a team's load.
A feature that allows the application of tags to individual Outlook items to specify retention policy for that message, conversation or other item.
A navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer and other internet browsers.

Information that describes the current location of a computer. The location is entered manually in Default Location, and can be used by programs to determine the location of a computer when a location sensor is unavailable.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.

A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.
A small, affordable laptop that is designed to perform a limited number of tasks such as web browsing and e-mail.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.
A feature that ensures that all components of a file are preserved, even if they are supported only by the rich client and not viewable in Web Companions.
A customizable page that launches with Windows Live Messenger and features a summary of news and weather, allows a customer to preview their Windows Live Mail inbox and search the Internet.
A text box where someone enters the e-mail addresses of the primary recipients of an e-mail message.

A set of features that enables users to improve the quality of their images with just one or two clicks. Galleries help the user optimize characteristics such as brightness, contrast, color, and sharpness.
A feature that enables Tablet PC users to convert an ink drawing to a standard OfficeArt shape, which can be formatted with colors and effects exactly as if it were inserted using “Insert Shape.”

A feature that enables presenters to capture all the elements of a live presentation, including narration, slides, mouse clicks, A/V playback, and laser pointer highlights. The user can select which presentation aspects to record.
A map view created from aerial photos that shows buildings, roads, and geographical features.

A slide show mode that displays content in a manageable window that can be resized and features navigation buttons. This mode is optimized for reviewing presentations, allowing users to get the full experience, complete with animations and media, while performing other tasks, such as taking notes.

A feature that allows users to easily add links to content within other content (e.g. pages, sections, section groups) and provides quick navigation through these links. The feature operates in the same manner that links work in wikis.
A feature that highlights new or changed content in a shared notebook that the user has not yet read.
A high-level linear representation of a project schedule that can be easily formatted, annotated, and copied and pasted from Project into other Office applications.
A feature that identifies the author of unread new or changed content in a shared notebook.
The combination of hardware (touchscreen or touchpad) and software elements that provides a way to control programs by touching multiple points on the screen simultaneously.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.

A feature that allows users to see conflicting appointments directly from Mail view without having to switch to Calendar view. Makes it much easier for users to decide to accept or decline a meeting invite that conflicts with an existing meeting.

A Microsoft Office Online application that enables users to upload, view (in full fidelity with animations and transitions maintained), share, and edit PPT files in a Web browser, as well as create basic presentations using only the Web client. They can also take those PPT presentations and embed them in other Web applications, like blog postings or other Web sites.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to images to create a customized, artistic look.
A gallery of effects that users can apply to videos to create a customized, artistic look.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A specification according to which each open document occupies its own window in the UI, though only a single instance of the program application is running.
A flexible bounding box that contains the notes that you type or paste on a page.
The feature that allows users to stream music, images or videos to a specific device on their home network.
To enter information by means of the keyboard or other input method.
A type of conditional formatting that is configured within Microsoft SQL Server Analysis Services.
A site element that stores and displays a collection of data that team members and other site users can share.
A video clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
An audio clip that has been inserted into another file or Web page.
A standard control that resembles a notebook and lets the user navigate different sections of information without leaving the current element on the screen.
To join or combine thereby increasing the quantity or size of something.

A “software-plus-services” platform and experience that enables PCs and other devices to “come alive” by making them aware of each other through the Internet, enabling individuals and organizations to manage, access, and share their files and applications seamlessly on the Web and across their world of devices.
A UI or media segment that can display on top of or play concurrently with another UI or media segment.
To return to a stable condition after some error has occurred. A program recovers from an error by stabilizing itself and resuming execution of instructions without user intervention.
A collection of statistics that indicates the degree to which a service meets performance, usage, and other demands for the service.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A feed that provides information, notifications and updates based on people, documents, and tags you are following.
A synchronous event whose handler runs completely before the action that raised the event starts.
The link to the form where a user can report violations of the terms of use. Contextually, it's understood that the abuse in question is poor conduct, such as obscene language or threats.
A process, thread, or set of related processes or threads that requires significant system resources or time, or requires exclusive access to large amounts of data.

A custom solution that can be deployed to a site by a site collection administrator, without approval from the farm administrator. Without that approval, the solution has full access to the immediate site and restricted access to system resources and other sites.
A custom keyword or description and shortcut to a Web page or item on a SharePoint site or the Internet. All of these tags can be viewed, managed, and shared by using My Site.
A collection of features that can be used to store and share comments, shortcuts, descriptions, and other information about Web pages and items on a SharePoint site or the Internet.
A statistic that indicates the degree to which a computer, server farm, or server cluster meets usage demands for that configuration.
The main landing or start page on Windows Live.
The button next to a search box that someone clicks to search for something.
The status menu item that makes it appear to the user’s contacts that he or she is currently offline.
A process that restricts the flow of data.
The process by which organizations find, retain, and preserve electronic documents related to a legal action.
A collection of files, settings, databases, and auxiliary information that is packaged as a file structure or as a compressed file for deployment.
A telecommunications standard that lets users send and receive messages that include rich text, images, audio, and video.
The Windows Live service that lets someone set up dynamic photo collections or other media sources to stream into a digital photo frame, or any RSS-enabled device.
The file name extension of a data file that stores your messages and other items on your computer.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
A desktop app that enables WYSIWYG editing, offline editing, and preview functionality.
The web browser toolbar that provides quick access to Windows Live services, plus optional features to customize the browsing experience.
Software and the supporting service that enable the synchronization of files between computers and with online storage, of program settings between PCs, and the remote connection to a PC.

The Windows Live service that enables a user to create a personal website where they can create and update a blog, and share their photos, music playlists and more, to connect with friends, family, or the online world.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
The Microsoft online service that lets users access and share documents, photos, and other files from anywhere.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.
A desktop app that enables users to view, manage, edit, and share photos and videos.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.

An instant messaging and video chat service designed for a consumer audience (not for the enterprise). Messenger is available via a desktop app, on the web (no installation needed), and on mobile devices.
The desktop e-mail program that lets users manage multiple e-mail accounts, newsgroups, and feeds in one place.
A task page in the Windows Control Panel from where customers can get real-time status information about their network, and also make changes to settings.

An area in a window in which commands and other controls are displayed in functionally related groups. A ribbon can be divided into multiple views, known as tabs, and every tab can contain multiple groups of controls. Typically, a ribbon appears at the top of a window.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.
The web email service for domains supported by Microsoft account, including @hotmail.com and @live.com.

The web service where users can share their thoughts, photographs, and interests with all members of a group. Members all contribute to a group profile, and can post blog entries, photos, and other items, just as they can to an individual profile.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.
The set of Microsoft software for email, instant messaging, photos, and personal movies available to customers in a single download and installation.

The Windows Live universal roaming contact list that allows users to share their contact information and subscribe to others’ to automatically receive updates across Windows Live Messenger and Windows Live Spaces.
The Windows Live service that allows users to make computer-to-computer or computer-to-phone calls. Users must be signed in to Windows Live Messenger to use it.
The Windows Live service that lets people and groups add, manage, and share event information.
The Windows Live service that notifies someone of an event or information based on their subscription preferences. The alerts can be sent to Messenger, Mail, Hotmail, or a mobile device.
The category of services that includes OneDrive, Outlook.com, and Skype.
Pertaining to a search process enabled by a particular technology.
The Microsoft service that facilitates web searches.
A feature that displays the first three lines of a message in the user's Inbox.
The website where customers add computers (both PCs and Macs), mobile phones, and digital photo frames so they can access their synced folders and connect remotely to their devices.

A geographical area that observes the same local time. The local time has a positive, zero, or negative offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). The offset can be different during standard time and daylight saving time.
An option that creates a meeting request from the selected e-mail message.
An option that creates a meeting request from the selected e-mail message.
A ribbon group that provides options for drawings created with pen and ink tools.
A server technology enabling users to load, calculate, and display Excel workbooks on Microsoft Office SharePoint Server.
A removable storage device that has been configured with Office applications using the Office To-Go Device Manager.

descripGrp.descrip: The portion of data distribution that is determined to be more or less than some critical value. For example, the far left and far right areas of a bell curve.

A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected if the value of the test statistic falls into either tail of the probability distribution (i.e. is either less than a first critical value or greater than a second critical value).

A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected if the value of the test statistic falls into either tail of the probability distribution (i.e. is either less than a first critical value or greater than a second critical value).
An option that isolates the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
A slider control where the maximum and minimum values of the range can be modified.
A feature that contains galleries where the user can create, store, and find reusable pieces of content, including AutoText, document properties, fields and building blocks.
A defined point in a workflow that is entered when specified conditions are met.

A feature that uses speech recognition to enable you to interact with your computer or other devices by voice. You can dictate documents and e-mails in mainstream applications, and use voice commands to start and switch between applications, control the operating system and even fill out forms on the web.
A text-based post on Twitter.
An item in the global address list that provides an easy way to send messages to a group of people. A public group can include any item from a global address list, including other public groups.
An add-in for Microsoft Excel that you can build with any compiler that supports building DLLs (dynamic link libraries).
The Bing service that allows search and view of maps and satellite images.
The year 2010 basic ad-supported edition of the Microsoft spreadsheet software with tools for analyzing, charting, and communicating data.
A written record of a meeting that includes information such as the subject, participants, key discussion points and action items.
A feature that displays a list of frequently used contacts and allows the user to initiate communication directly from that list.
The phone number for a mobile phone.
The main Excel Services component, which loads the spreadsheet and workbook, calculates the spreadsheets, updates external data, and maintains session state for interactivity.
An annotation that describes or emphasizes an element of a drawing or image and is typically connected to that drawing or image by a line.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.
Descriptive text that represents the audio content of a television or video program as text on the screen. Captions are usually visible only if decoded or activated.

A viewer that allows users to display PowerPoint presentations on a phone’s browser. A file is rendered as an HTML page with sufficient fidelity to display readable slide and outline views on a small screen.
To send an instant message.
In typography, a single character created from two joined letters that replaces the two separate letters.
A tab on the ribbon that takes users to Microsoft Office Backstage view.
A feature of Microsoft Office that allows the user to view and edit image document formats like .TIF, which is the format most traditionally used in fax transmissions (IOs, T&Cs, etc.).
A feature of Microsoft Office that allows the user to view and edit image document formats like .TIF, which is the format most traditionally used in fax transmissions (IOs, T&Cs, etc.).
A free online service that enables Office users to share presentations with people who view them on the web.
A converter that supports dynamic viewing of PowerPoint presentations (with animation) in a Web environment.
A guide used to position shapes and objects on slides.
A converter that supports static viewing of PowerPoint presentations (without animation) in a Web environment.

A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected if the value of the test statistic falls into a specific tail of the probability distribution (e.g. the test statistic must be greater than a critical value in order to reject the null hypothesis).

A test in which the null hypothesis is rejected if the value of the test statistic falls into a specific tail of the probability distribution (e.g. the test statistic must be greater than a critical value in order to reject the null hypothesis).
A special-purpose terminal that bank customers can use to make deposits, obtain cash, and perform other transactions.
In statistics, a list or a function that describes the probabilities of the possible values of a random variable chosen by means of a Bernoulli sampling process.

An e-mail program originally introduced by cc:mail, Inc., and currently produced by the Lotus Development Corporation. Lotus cc:Mail runs on multiple networking platforms and the Internet and is closely integrated with Lotus Notes collaborative software.

A specialized activation option available for approved Microsoft Volume Licensing customers that enables customers to use public key infrastructure (PKI) and digital certificates (or “tokens,” typically stored on smart cards) to activate Windows Vista Enterprise and Windows Server 2008 SP2 locally without contacting either customer-hosted KMS or the Microsoft-hosted activation service using MAK.
A gallery to which users can add reusable content to be displayed in Quick Parts and the Building Blocks Organizer.
An online process that confirms whether installed software was properly activated.
A format for user assistance content that presents simple steps on a given topic that enable a user to begin using a feature quickly.
A SharePoint service application that is deployed and managed on premises and that enables enterprise search functionality.
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
The link to the personal page where users can store information (such as personal interests) and links (such as to friends and photos).
The link to the list of contacts from your mail and messenger accounts.
The link to Windows Live Hotmail.
The link to the list of more links to other Microsoft sites.
The link to the online calendar on Windows Live Calendar.
The link to the online shared event organiser on Windows Live Events.
The link to the online communities on Windows Live Groups.
The link to the user's personal online space, with blog functionality, photo albums, and lists, on Windows Live Spaces.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the site to manage online access rights for, and monitor internet usage of, family members on Windows Live Family Safety.
The link to the Windows Live site where users can register their mobile phone and find information about the Windows Live for Mobile services.
The link to the site to download client versions of Windows Live products such as Windows Live Mail, Windows Live Messenger, etc.
The link to the overview page of all Windows Live, MSN, and Microsoft products on offer.
The link to the page where users enter information for the methods by which they can be contacted, such as Messenger, home phone, mobile phone, and e-mail.
An option that enables the user to see the different parts of a nested formula evaluated in the order the formula is calculated.
The year 2010 edition of the Microsoft spreadsheet software with tools for analyzing, charting, and communicating data.
The year 2010 edition of the Microsoft spreadsheet software, with tools for analyzing, charting, and communicating data, designed for home and students.
The year 2010 edition of the Microsoft spreadsheet software designed for use with handheld computing devices.
A device that runs Windows Phone Operating System.
The menu item on the Bing menu that links to http://www.bing.com/cashback/.
The Web page object that assists users in finding both public (Web and Windows Live) and private (my Windows Live content) content for insertion into their authored content.
The link to the free online workspace for accessing, editing, and sharing Excel, Word, PowerPoint and OneNote documents across your PC, smartphone, and web browser.
The link to bing.com in some regions but to a dropdown list of more Bing options in other regions.
The Windows Mobile header link that opens a menu that contains more options.
The link to the website where customers add computers (both PCs and Macs), mobile phones, and digital photo frames so they can access their synced folders and connect remotely to their devices.
The link to the code of conduct, which contains rules that explain how someone should behave while using a service or product.
The year 2010 edition of the Microsoft messaging and collaboration client software for personal computers accessing Microsoft Exchange Server-based email and collaboration services.
The link to photos that only you and people that you select can view (versus public photos that anyone can view).
The link to the Microsoft service agreement.
The Windows Mobile footer link to the site that is built for viewing from a PC.
The Windows Mobile footer link to the site that is built for viewing from mobile devices.
A network made of people or organizations linked by some type of social relationship.
A short summary of the contents of a document that gives the reader a quick overview of its topic and purpose.

A set of features that incorporates elements of social networking into the Outlook experience. It provides relevant contextual information about the people whom users interact with in Outlook, based on local data (e-mail and calendar items) and social activity (news feeds and status updates).

A set of features that incorporates elements of social networking into the Outlook experience. It provides relevant contextual information about the people whom users interact with in Outlook, based on local data (e-mail and calendar items) and social activity (news feeds and status updates).
A pane in Outlook that displays a selected contact along with relevant information (photos, status messages or feeds, calendar items, etc.) from Outlook and other networks.
A view that displays a profile photo of everyone who is part of an e-mail thread or calendar item.
A feature of Outlook that allows members of an organization to be displayed in a tree view control, grouped by department.
A feature of Outlook that allows members of an organization to be displayed in a tree view control, grouped by department.
An option presented to the user through a right-click menu that simplifies common Office tasks and provides more control over automatic features.
An action that can be enabled to identify and provide conversions for international units of measurement.
The Excel Services component that provides programmatic access to its Web service.
A version of the OpenDocument Format (ODF) v1.1 file format for presentations.
A menu item that opens a Live Meeting invitation in Outlook. Available with the Conferencing Add-in for Outlook.

descripGrp.descrip: A menu item which enables the user to permanently move a calendar to a different time zone.
A menu item in Microsoft Powerpoint which enables the user to start the sound at a certain point in its playing time.
In Microsoft Outlook, an add-in which creates backup copies of .PST files at regular intervals, enabling the user to keep Outlook folders safely backed up.
In Microsoft Outlook, an add-in which creates backup copies of .PST files at regular intervals, enabling the user to keep Outlook folders safely backed up.

descripGrp.descrip: The first word or words in a paragraph or sentence.

A user-interface element that contains information about actions that you recently performed in a list. You can double click on the message bar to get more information about a specific action that you performed.
An interactive and flexible data filter that always conveys the current filtering state.
A tab character that can be inserted in headers and footers for aligning data relative to the margin or indent. If you change the margin/indent, the text is realigned automatically.
The listing of contents created by bookmarking blocks of text and creating the table of contents of the bookmarked area.
The window that contains the user's workbook of tabbed sheets.
A prewritten formula that simplifies the process of entering calculations and enables the user to use formulas that might be difficult to build from scratch.

A type of Human Interaction Proof challenge, which plays an audio file decipherable only by a person. The audio file might seem faint or mixed with background voices and noise. This is intentional to ensure a person, not an automated program, completes the HIP challenge.
A range of cells in a worksheet that has been formatted as a table and can be managed independently from the data in other rows and columns on the worksheet.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal in width to the point size of a particular font. For many fonts, this is equal to the width of a capital N, from which the en space takes its name.
A user who regularly files mailbox items into folders.
A user who regularly files mailbox items into folders.
A site that provides social networking capabilities.
A site that provides social networking capabilities.
A view for delivering a presentation that displays it as the audience will see it.
A view for delivering a presentation that displays it as the audience will see it.
A control that is used to select a sheet within a workbook.
A note that displays the translation of a word in a document when the user moves the mouse pointer over the word.
The display name UI label used when there isn’t a display name value available, as when data can't be retrieved or someone hasn’t completely filled out their profile.
To add a personal touch to something.
The webpage subheading for the view in Messenger that displays someone's friends and contacts that aren't friends but that can be interacted with in Messenger (those are often legacy entries).
An equation written using a stylus on a Tablet PC.
An application that is meant to run on a desktop computer.
The feature that gives users a rich way to send video messages asynchronously to another user.
A small icon, image or title that is associated with a user's name and that provides a visual indication of their role, contribution level, or other achievement or affiliation.
A recording that can be added to a presentation.
A collection of formatting options (Quick Styles) that are designed to be used together.

To remove the ability of a network object, such as a user account or a network-joined computer to access the resources that the server provides. Deactivating a network object does not delete the object from the active directory, nor does it delete any data that is associated with the object.
A person someone has established a mutual connection with. The connection could have been made on Windows Live or in any connected social networking service.

A content processing feature that extracts information from unstructured text in an item and stores that information as additional managed properties for the item. The additional managed properties can be used to refine results.
The UI label in Messenger for the results list of a contacts search.
The UI label for a permissions setting that indicates an item is being shared with (made available to) all of someone's friends.
A presentation method in Messenger that allows someone to maintain multiple conversations in a tabbed view.
A webpage link saved as a .url file in someone's "Favorites" folder on Windows OneDrive. Favorites can be created directly within OneDrive, or via the Windows Live Toolbar.

A mechanism for a MAPI client to initiate a quick shutdown of the client process, notifying all providers with which the client has an active MAPI session to save data and settings before the client process exits.
A file that contains the unique information for each data-merged document.
A single document that is converted as part of a conversion.

In Windows Live (primarily through profile), online actions, such as updating a status message, publishing photos, or updating profile info. These actions can take place on Windows Live or on other services someone has connected to their profile, such as Facebook or Twitter. These actions can show up as updates in feeds within Windows Live or on connected services.
A reference to a table or subset of a table by the table name and column specifier instead of cell coordinates.
An application service for storing and handling an organization's documents.

An action taken on Windows Live or on partner websites such as Facebook that is considered to have social relevance and that might appear in an activity feed. For example, photo activity and status updates are considered to be socially relevant. Within Windows Live, friends see one another's relevant actions in feeds within Messenger, on Windows Live Home, and other places. Depending on the partner and their settings, actions that a customer takes on Windows Live may be visible on partner sites, actions they take on partner sites may be visible on Windows Live, or both.
A change to a document that is indicated with a revision mark.
The checkbox customers select to include their spaces blog in the updates that they share about themselves. This text links to Spaces.
Software or web service that provides an anonymous proxy designed to make user identity untraceable.
The tooltip displayed when pointing to a personal folder icon on the Manage folders page on the Windows Live Devices website.

A website or service that a customer can connect in order to share what they've been doing on other websites, see their friends and their updates from other services in Windows Live, or share their Windows Live activity on other websites.
A folder someone using Windows Live Sync is synchronizing between computers.
The feature that allows users to navigate directly to the webpage of the top-ranked search result when a search is performed in the address bar.

descripGrp.descrip: The return to a customer's account of funds that were used to purchase an item. This may occur as a result of a customer's contacting a bank to dispute a credit-card transaction.
An audience member who is not physically located in the same room as the presenter.
A folder that's automatically added to OneDrive when photos are uploaded from Windows Phone.
A series of equations that are stacked vertically, and that can be aligned at a particular character if desired.
A space in a template where a user can type text or insert symbols.
A slot where the user can type text.
The combined schedule of a number of people or resources.
A set of integrated linguistic references and resources that are designed to help Office users for whom English is not a first language to write better English text.
A tax on products at each stage of their production based on the value added during that stage.
The upper limit in a permitted range of values.
Persons who exist in no programmatic feature category, or more than one category.
A computer that a customer adds to their Windows Live account security information from which they can reset a forgotten password without providing further information.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
The public multinational corporation that develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of products and services predominantly related to computing.
A visual representation such as a picture, chart or table.
A service under which customers can acquire and redeem points for certain online services and digital products.
A process of repeated installation of a product, feature, tool, kit, pack, etc.
An operating-system installation and configuration that uses a virtual hard disk as the running operating system. There is no host operating system or hypervisor in a native-boot configuration.
The authorization given by a payer to a payee, or by the institution with which the payer's account is held, consenting to the debiting of the payer's account.
A tablet-style portable computer that's designed for touch input and that lacks an integrated physical keyboard.

A source that returns a set of search results for a given search query. The source can be a search service in the local server farm or another server farm, or another search engine that is compliant with the OpenSearch protocol.
A Web Part that renders named objects or named items in a workbook, such as tables, charts, slicers or a named range of cells.

A symmetric encryption key shared by two entities, such as between a user and the domain controller (DC), with a long lifetime. A password is a common example of a secret key. When used in a context that implies Kerberos only, a principal's secret key.

A Microsoft Office Web Component that provides interactive charting functionality on a Web page. You can illustrate data in a chart and give users the ability to change data, change chart options, and see changes reflected in the chart.
A character that is part of the set that makes up a particular language, such as vowels and consonants.
An application that parses code and markup in a page to help ensure that only trusted code and markup is run on a computer, server farm, or server cluster.
The area of the Help window that contains a Help topic.
A list that identifies which assemblies and types are allowed to run on Web Parts pages in a server farm. The list is stored in the web.config file for the server farm.
A measure whose value is calculated at run time by using an expression.
A high resolution, tag-based graphics format, based on the Tagged Image File Format (TIFF) used for digital graphics.

The folder in which various translated files are stored. Each language has a different subfolder that corresponds to its locale identification number (LCID). For example, in a U.S. English installation, the LCID is 1033.

Software that enhances the functionality of Microsoft Office 2002 and your Web browser by extending the functionality of a Web server to provide publishing, collaboration, and document management capabilities.
A toolbar with buttons and options used to apply text formatting. To display the toolbar, point to Toolbars on the View menu, and then click Formatting.

A Visual Basic identifier that's defined in the host application or by using the #Const compiler directive, and used by other compiler directives to determine when or if certain blocks of code are compiled.
A Naskh script that enriches the display of Arabic text. This script uses object linking and embedding (OLE) to create and add objects to a document.
A Ruq'ah script that enriches the display of Arabic text. This script uses object linking and embedding (OLE) to create and add objects to a document.
An administrative tool that examines a computer, server farm, or server cluster and provides statistics that indicate the degree to which the configuration meets expected demands.
A custom handler that calls and runs custom code during the creation process for a site.
A Microsoft Office program that you can use to organize related documents. You can check spelling, number pages consecutively across all documents in the binder, and print the documents.
A contiguous piece of text or string of characters sharing the same attributes. All characters in a run have the same directional properties.

A reading order and alignment setting that is commonly used in controls that display text. When you select the Context setting, the reading order is determined by the first strong character (not a numeral or special character) that you type.
In an outline, to change a heading to body text or to a lower heading level: for example, to change from Heading 5 to Heading 6.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A demonstration of a product or service that a customer interacts with to see how features work.
A setting that allows a user to turn off cellular, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth on the phone simultaneously. Often required during takeoff and landing in an aircraft.
The actual software bits available to developers to enable them to use the Live Connect program.
A Microsoft sub-brand grouping digital-media products, including devices that play media, a software media player, and online media services.
The collection title for musical artists that are in the top N% of sales/plays.
An Outlook contact’s residential telephone number (usually a land line).
Usually the spouse or domestic partner of a contact. Detail that can be added to a contact’s profile, listed under "other."
The collection title for music albums that are in the top N% of sales/plays.
A tile that updates dynamically to show content directly from the Start screen.
Logo assigned to the products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the software products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
Logo assigned to the hardware products that have passed Microsoft designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A program designed to identify compatible and reliable systems, software, and hardware products that have passed Microsoft-designed tests for compatibility and reliability on Windows 7.
A user account that has been assigned as an administrator for the tenant.
A program used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
To display an address or location on a map.
The time or times during the day that a child is restricted from using the computer.
The number of hours or minutes per day that a child is allowed to use the computer.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.
A program that shows details about a computer's hardware configuration, computer components, and software, including drivers.
The UI label in Messenger for the aspect of the social view that displays unprioritized recent social activity of friends.
The UI label in Messenger for the aspect of the social view that displays unprioritized recent social activity of the user.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.

The infrastructure that manages low-level graphics-related tasks, such as output adapter and swap chain configuration, and provides a common framework for managing virtualized graphics components and resources.
A continuous sequence of characters that share a common format.
A function or object that invokes an event handler when a specific condition occurs in an application.
A contiguous run of sectors on one disk.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CA’s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.

A certificate extension that contains information useful for verifying the trust status of a certificate, as defined by the 2008 Memo of the Network Working Group. This information potentially includes Uniform Resource Locations (URLs) where the issuing CA’s certificate can be retrieved, as well as a location of an Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) responder configured to provide status for the certificate in question.

descripGrp.descrip: A certificate extension that indicates where the certificate revocation list for a CA can be retrieved. It can contain none, one, or many HTTP, file, or LDAP URLs.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.
In a public key infrastructure hierarchy, the certification authority that that issues certificates to users and computers.

A protocol that allows real-time validation of a certificate’s status by having the CryptoAPI make a call to an OCSP responder and the OCSP responder providing an immediate validation of the revocation status for the presented certificate. Typically, an OCSP responder responds with the revocation status check request based on the certificate revocation list (CRL) or other forms of revocation status it retrieves from the certification authorities.

A protocol that allows real-time validation of a certificate’s status by having the CryptoAPI make a call to an OCSP responder and the OCSP responder providing an immediate validation of the revocation status for the presented certificate. Typically, an OCSP responder responds with the revocation status check request based on the certificate revocation list (CRL) or other forms of revocation status it retrieves from the certification authorities.

descripGrp.descrip: A configuration mode for the Certificate Enrollment Web Service in which it will only process renewal requests.
A hexadecimal string that contains the SHA-1 hash of the certificate.

In Server Manager and Event Viewer, the urgency of an event or error condition, system fault, failure, or action by either the system or the user. Severity can be any of four industry-standard values: Information, Warning, Error, or Critical. These values are defined in the Event Viewer Help.
A process that builds one or more certificate paths. The certificate paths may or may not trace up to a self-signed or root certificate.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. The AKI can contain the issuer name, serial number, public key information, or no information at all. By matching the information in a certificate’s AKI extension to a CA certificate’s Subject Key Identifier (SKI) extension, a certificate chain can be built.

A certificate extension used by the certificate chaining engine to determine what certificate was used to sign a presented certificate. A tool used to collect the formatting of an existing table border so that it can be applied to another border.
A set of APIs for SharePoint products. These APIs are based on the server object model, and can be called from clients such as desktop PCs and mobile devices.
A set of APIs for SharePoint products. These APIs are based on the server object model, and can be called from clients such as desktop PCs and mobile devices.
A site template that is designed to create an online community where people come together to share ideas or get answers to their questions.
A feature that extends AutoComplete functionality to show a live preview of suggested values for an entire range of cells based on what the user is typing.

A set of controls that helps users navigate directly to where they want to go in SharePoint, without having to navigate the hierarchy or edit the URL.
A feature that enables subscription customers to launch Office rich client applications online from a computer on which those applications are not already installed.
A feature that enables users to edit SharePoint list content directly without opening an edit window.
An error log that contains errors and exceptions that occur when SharePoint tries to connect to external systems through Business Connectivity Services. It can be retrieved by tenant administrators.

descripGrp.descrip: A feature in the Outlook calendar that can be enabled to display the weather forecast for a selected location.

A contextual summary of the user's task list, which is displayed in a callout without switching to the Tasks module.
A tab in the Backstage view where users can manage their identities and services, view licensing details, and link to account management features.

A high-level view in Visual Designer that shows the stages of a SharePoint workflow, rather than individual actions or conditions.
A feature that enables Exchange users to see new email messages and up-to-date calendar items as soon as they open Outlook, without waiting for it to finish synchronizing.
A web experience on Office.com that enables users to manage their Office licenses and subscriptions.

A SharePoint document library that administrators can use to distribute apps for Office and SharePoint to their end users.
An individual page in a topic series, or any page that is primarily search-driven.
A storage method in which a file is split into pieces that are stored and updated separately, and streamed together when a user requests the file.

A file that stores information about compatibility issues and workarounds and makes it available to the Office Telemetry Log and Office Telemetry Dashboard.
A SharePoint document library in which content is stored after being deleted or modified so that it can be accessed for electronic discovery or other legal purposes.
An attack where a malicious website makes an HTTP request to a target website in such a way that the website thinks that the request is part of a legitimate user’s session.
An attack where a malicious website makes an HTTP request to a target website in such a way that the website thinks that the request is part of a legitimate user’s session.
A predetermined value that must be present in a client-server request for the request to be considered valid.
A predetermined value that must be present in a client-server request for the request to be considered valid.
A tool that enables IT pros to monitor usage, error, and compatibility issue information from Office related solutions on client machines across an organization.
A metadata column or field in a Key Filters control.
A dashboard where admins can track the overall health of the apps in a site collection or tenancy.
An online view of data that provides an enhanced visual experience through tables, slicers, charts, and other Excel objects.
A gallery of objects that provides different ways of visualizing data.
A contextual summary of the user's favorite contacts and People search functionality, which is displayed in a callout without switching to the People view.
A rule that an administrator can configure and apply to query processing to help optimize results and create an enhanced user experience.
Pertaining to the chrome-free UI presentation mode that fills all or a portion of the display.
A URL that is directly accessible over the Internet and that does not require special credentials or network access to connect to it.
A URL that is directly accessible over the Internet and that does not require special credentials or network access to connect to it.

A secondary encryption key that provides the ability for an authorized IT Helpdesk administrator to open an encrypted document when the password is lost.

A collection of keys or key and value pairs that is used for content or query processing in search.

The process of extracting information from unstructured text in an item and storing that information as additional managed properties for the item.
A content processing or query processing pipeline that contains operators that determine how the content or the query is processed.
A copy of a search index within an index partition.
An object that processes and enhances items in a content processing flow and processes and enhances queries in a query processing flow.
An XML document that describes how to rank items in search results.
A process that ensures that index replicas on the same index partition remain syncronized during regular operation and during recovery.
A collection of managed properties that are updated together in the search index.
A managed property that can be queried against. The query must contain the managed property field name, either in the query itself or programmatically.
A managed property that can be used as the basis for a refiner for search results.
A managed property that can be displayed in search results.

descripGrp.descrip: A managed property whose result set can be sorted based on the property before the result set is returned.

A user defined dictionary that lists single words or phrases that the system matches to words in the content in either a case-sensitive way or a case-insensitive way, depending on the type of dictionary that is used.

A custom extraction dictionary that lists words or phrases that are matched to exact words in the content in a case-sensitive way. For example, the system matches "anchor" to "anchor," but not to "Anchor" or "Anchorage."

A custom extraction dictionary that lists words or phrases that are matched anywhere in the content in a case-sensitive way. For example, the system matches "anchor" and "anchorage," but not "Anchor."

A custom extraction dictionary that lists words or phrases that are matched to exact words in the content in a case-insensitive way. For example, the entry "anchor" will match "anchor" and "Anchor," but not "anchorage."

A custom extraction dictionary that lists words or phrases that are matched anywhere in the content in a case-insensitive way. For example, the entry "anchor" will match "anchor," "Anchor," and "anchorage."
A data structure that describes crawled properties, managed properties, and the mapping between them.
A logical portion of the search index.
A set of apps that includes Messenger, Photo Gallery, Movie Maker, OneDrive, Mail, Writer, and Family Safety. (Family Safety is only included in Windows 7 downloads; it's built in to Windows 8.)

A tool in Office 365 that enables IT professionals to manage how Office is installed for their users. Users receive the correct language and configurations individually tailored to them automatically, without the need to install anything themselves.
A mode in which SharePoint Server is the primary source for all the project details. Project Server scheduling, time and status, and advanced functionality are disabled.

A Windows feature that enables users to connect computers with a simple tap gesture or by browsing for computers within wireless range. If two computers come within 3-4 centimeters of each other, or are tapped together, the operating system of each computer becomes aware of the other computer. Also, a user can browse for computers within wireless range that are advertising for a peer connection. The user can then connect the two computers to share content such as photos or links, or create a multi-player experience. If the connection is made using a tap gesture, the user can also publish and subscribe to messages transmitted during the tap.
A feature of Windows where a user's credentials are securely stored.
To take action on an email message by either replying to the sender, to the sender and all recipients, or by forwarding the email to someone else.
A pane in the Outlook window that contains folders for each view, such as Mail or Calendar.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A feature of Windows that provide right-click access from taskbar program buttons to the documents, pictures, songs, or websites a user frequently accesses.
A nonfinal release of Internet Explorer 10.
A short video sent as an email message to someone in the contact list.
A short video sent as an email message to someone in the contact list.
A technique that increases sharpness and fidelity by compensating for some effects that camera movement has on images in videos.
A technique that increases sharpness and fidelity by compensating for some effects that camera movement has on images in videos.

The cloud service that enables users to communicate and collaborate with people online and access their conversations, photos, documents, contacts, appointments, settings, and services across PC, phone, and other devices.
A user action that is counted and analyzed by the recommendations algorithm in the Analytics Service.
A metadata navigation control that enables users to limit the items displayed in a list or library to those that match selected values.

A feature that allows for preservation of content documents, pages, and messages in Exchange and SharePoint so that when they are modified or deleted, the original version can still be accessed for electronic discovery and other legal purposes.
The screen that appears when a user locks the PC.
A tool that allows users to upload email messages, email folders, and contacts from an email account on their PC to the cloud to facilitate access from multiple devices.
An image stabilization technique used to remove wobbled distortions from a video captured with a rolling shutter camera that's exposed to large accelerations or jitter.
An image stabilization technique that's used to reduce the appearance of camera shake in a video image.
An image stabilization technique that's used to reduce the appearance of camera shake in a video image.

A Microsoft Office product that identifies business-critical Excel spreadsheets and Access databases by discovering files across network shares and SharePoint libraries, and that provides flexible risk assessment and categorization based on relevance, materiality and business impact.
A Microsoft Office product that provides interactive diagnostics to identify errors, deviations from spreadsheet best practices and insights into data flow in and out of the spreadsheet.
A Microsoft Office product that detects and categorizes changes between two spreadsheets to facilitate review and approval processes.
A Microsoft Office product that detects and categorizes changes between two databases to facilitate review and approval processes.

A Microsoft Office product that provides non-intrusive auditing of changes made to Excel spreadsheets and Access databases, and supports alerts, notifications and automatic workflows based on user activities such as macro or formula changes.
The web browser component of Windows that provides a traditional and familiar browsing experience.
The touch-optimized, immersive web browser for Windows.
A document service that enables organizations to provision and manage online storage for their users.
A document service that enables organizations to provision and manage online storage for their users.

A section in the default OneNote notebook where certain notes are stored by default.
A tab available to users who are signed in on Office.com where they can launch Office on Demand and access their most recently used online documents and folders.
A gesture that enables proximity-based authentication between two devices.

descripGrp.descrip: An action by which a subscription (the source subscription) is replaced by a new subscription, both owned by the same billing account, along a preconfigured conversion path. The source subscription is canceled and the destination subscription is the new subscription.
A new subscription that is created as a result of a conversion or a merge.
A subscription that is canceled to create a new subscription as a result of a conversion or merge.
A partner in scenarios where the partner providing the offer is different than the partner providing the service, for example, Xbox selling Messenger products.
Replace a set of subscriptions with a new subscription.
The process of activating tokens during a purchase.
The process of activating tokens during a purchase.
A subscription that can only be paid with a prepaid card.

The operating system designed for enthusiasts and business/technical pros that includes all of the features in Windows 8, plus features for encryption, virtualization, PC management, and domain connectivity.

The operating system for PCs and tablets powered by x86 (32-bit) and AMD (64-bit) processors that includes an updated Windows Explorer, Task Manager, better multi-monitor support, and fast language switching.

The operating system only available pre-installed on PCs and tablets powered by ARM processors that helps enable new thin and lightweight form factors with impressive battery life. Windows RT includes touch-optimized versions of Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and OneNote.
A downloadable pack that adds features to Windows 8 or Windows 8 Single Language editions to move them to a Windows 8 Pro edition with Windows Media Center installed.
An edition of Windows 8 that is available only through volume licensing.
An edition of Windows 8 designed to make Windows affordable to mainstream consumers in emerging markets.
A media pack add-on to Windows 8 Pro that upgrades the edition to include Windows Media Center.

An Exchange mailbox that is associated with a SharePoint site, enabling users to access documents and email related to group projects through either Outlook or SharePoint.

A feature that enables rich visualizations for interactive data exploration, presentation and reporting in SharePoint and Excel.
The release candidate release of the Windows 8 operating system.

An automated proactive scan that triggers when NTFS detects a corruption. The scan is equivalent to the scan phase of chkdsk and finds and logs all corruptions to an internal file. This scan runs during maintenance hours, can be triggered from the Explorer, or manually run from a command line. When this scan is running in the background, some NTFS operations may be blocked.

A registry setting that allows the DHCP client to transmit more messages to the server to obtain an IP address when the PC is in connected standby mode. This setting can increase power consumption but can also help resolve IP address (IPv4 or IPv6) problems more quickly.
