descripGrp.descrip: A service within Remote Desktop Services responsible for aggregating RemoteApp programs and desktops that are published to end users from across the entire deployment. It ensure only users with appropriate rights can access published resources. The resources are used to display error messages that, for example, might say that the publishing service is unavailable. This can help the admin debug their deployment.
The capability to sign in to a PC by using a four-digit code.
A software setting that disables display rotation.
Collectively, the SharePoint service applications that write to ULS logs using shared code for automated document processing.
An instrumentation and logging platform that provides monitoring, reporting and log viewing capabilities for Office servers and services.
An instrumentation and logging platform that provides monitoring, reporting and log viewing capabilities for Office servers and services.

An application-hosting architecture that relies on cloud-based services. Application logic and data are typically hosted on a distributed set of services on the Internet, connected through web APIs, and authenticated with server-to-server authentication technologies such as OAuth.
A menu item that lets the user open a document using a different application than the one associated with the document type.
A function that returns the first non-null expression from a list of arguments.

An app for Mac computers that creates a folder on the user's computer, downloads the contents of their OneDrive, and keeps the folder in sync with any file changes online and among additional computers.
A feature that facilitates the use of Presenter View by automatically applying the Extend setting for Windows projection and identifying the correct display for Slide Show versus Presenter view.
A feature in Presenter View that enables the user to switch which monitor is showing Presenter View and which monitor is showing Slide Show.
An app that runs in a non-desktop app model, and runs on Windows, but is not necessarily sold or deployed via the Store.
A dropdown menu item or ribbon component that is added to a site page.
A type of custom action that is added to a host site by an app for SharePoint and that links to more functionality that is contained by the app.
A method of image acquisition in which each frame is recorded by vertically or horizontally scanning the frame.

The spreading of malicious content through online advertising.
A rating of how safe an app is determined to be by SmartScreen, according to age, presence of digital certificate, and other criteria.

The Japanese kana characters that indicate the correct pronunciation, sorting, and grouping behavior of a word written in kanji. The name of a field that stores such characters and can impact the sorting/grouping behavior of a corresponding field that can contain a word written in kanji. Typically used to modify the kanji field’s name (e.g. “Yomi Last Name” specifies how to correctly pronounce/sort/group “Last Name”). The main distinction compared to “phonetic” is that sorting/grouping behavior is expected to be impacted for “yomi”, but not for “phonetic”.
A feature that provides a progressive disclosure method that remains active only as long as the user holds (presses down) their finger on the touch surface.
The charm that provides access to the devices commands.
A hardware button that increases and decreases the sound volume.
The UI label that indicates a screen or monitor that is attached to a PC and that content can be projected on to.
An application that comes with a product key and DVD that allows users them to purchase Windows and activate their current copy of Windows from the client.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
A report generated by OEMs for each OA 3.0 manufactured computer which is then sent to Microsoft for processing. This report includes the hardware hash value and Product Key ID.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
The version of software that's distributed to manufacturers to build into hardware they will make available when the final software is made generally available.
To reset a system using a method that restores PC settings to defaults but retains a user's files and personalization touches.
To reset a system so that all user customizations are removed.
The service run by the Windows Store team that supports the end-to-end process for registering Windows Store developers and onboarding apps into the Windows Store catalog.
The service run by the Windows Store team that supports the end-to-end process for registering Windows Store developers and onboarding apps into the Windows Store catalog.
A control that slows down the speed of panning from a user interaction.
The button that allows customers to finalize their purchase on a website.
The out-of-the-box encryption capabilities that are automatically included on PCs running Windows RT.
The button on a checkout screen that, when clicked, commits the buyer to a purchase agreement with the seller, as specified by EU guideline 2011/83/EU and other local laws.

The feature of Bing that enables customers to block sites containing adult (sexually explicit) content. Customers can choose from three levels of filtering: strict (hides adult text and image results); moderate (hides adult images only); and off (doesn't hide any search results).

An app that's downloaded from the Windows Store and installed automatically to the PC when a user attaches a certified device to the PC, provided that the device manufacturer has submitted the app to the Windows Store.
The set of look-and-feel elements (type, color, icons, etc.) that create a sense of brand and a cohesive user experience with Microsoft products.
The Microsoft website of information on and resources for computer security, digital privacy, and online safety.
The Microsoft website of information on and resources for computer security, digital privacy, and online safety.

descripGrp.descrip: A pre-loaded app that allows users to better monitor and manage their data usage on their phone or PC. It can notify users when they are close to their cellular data limit and delay some data-intensive tasks until the phone or PC is connected to Wi-Fi.
A product that is used like a calling card, that allows a user to enter a number manually and dial any phone number. An Access number is a type of Skype To Go number.
The app that provides easy access to Help and how-to content as well as helpful tips for users.
A product that enables a user to call mobile phones and landlines from a mobile phone or landline via Skype.
A feature that enables the display of the caller's number on the callee's phone when calling a phone from Skype.
A feature that enables the display of the caller's number on the callee's phone when calling a phone from Skype.

A call to action on the skype.com homepage. Users can purchase Skype Credit to pay for using Skype products.
A Skype product; one of the possible ways to pay for using Skype products.
A feature that enables the user to see Skype activity, change settings, and purchase Skype Credit.
A feature that enables the user to see Skype activity, change settings, and purchase Skype Credit.
A Skype feature that enables automatic payments so that the user doesn't run out of Skype Credit.
A Skype feature that enables automatic payments so that the user doesn't run out of Skype Credit.
A feature that repeatedly redials the desired number until the user gets through.
The status that appears when a user is elsewhere than at their computer. The Away status can be selected manually when the user plans to be away, or automatically when the user has been away.

The memory available for storage of apps, games, media, settings, and more. It is an interface for users to see what is consuming the storage space on their phone, and functionality to move content from phone to SD card.
A feature that notifies the user about upcoming birthdays of contacts in the contact list.
The category of items that is personalized for the current user.
A traditional phone, which has a wired connection (as opposed to a mobile phone).
A feature that enables sharing video with other users live over the Internet.
A piece of information supplied by the user that appears in the mood panel beside the user's Skype Name for other users to see.
A field next to the user's Skype Name for typing a mood message.
A client service where users can ask for help via a live chat and a customer support agent will answer.

descripGrp.descrip: A unique user name for logging into the Skype client, a user's account, and so on.

An app, delivered in-box with Windows, that can be used to buy, stream, store, and sync music.
An app, delivered in-box with Windows, that can be used to buy, stream, store, and sync music.
To put your finger on a touchscreen and then swipe it quickly, lifting your finger off the screen, in the direction you want.
A Skype feature that allows users to call directly from Skype to landlines and mobile phones.
A feature that enables the user to store video clips.
A document that covers how users may use Skype software, Skype products, and the Skype website.
A feature that enables the user to connect to public WiFi hotspots, paying per minute with Skype Credit.

A phone number allocated for the Skype user, allowing the user to call pre-configured landlines or mobile phones. A type of Skype To Go number.

The status that a user selects when they are signed in but want to appear as offline to their contacts. They can send and receive IMs when invisible.

An organization that cooperates with Skype; the cooperation ranges from developing mutual software to selling products specially tailored for the organization.

To pay for a paid feature at the moment the feature is used. For example, to pay for Skype's calling phones feature with Skype Credit that is either already owned or purchased specially for the occasion.
To pay once a month for using Skype paid features such as calling phones or sending SMS messages; e.g., to pay for a monthly subscription.
A feature that enables users to preview photos and send them to contacts.

A picture taken with the webcam (during the call or any time).
A picture taken with the webcam (during the call or any time).
A feature that increases or decreases the volume of the speaker in a group call to match the position of the speaker (i.e right or left).

A part of a Skype subscription offer that allows a user to call to selected destination(s) within limits defined by the Fair Usage Policy.
Characteristic of a subscription which gives you, for a per-month fee, unlimited calls to a selected country/region; e.g. Unlimited Portugal.
A free internet call between two Skype users seeing each other via webcam.
A free internet call between two Skype users seeing each other via webcam.

A perceivable region of a webpage that is typically updated as a result of an external event when user focus may be elsewhere.

A user account and associated credentials that is used to access Microsoft’s and 3rd parties’ business services, such as Office 365. Work or school accounts are usually assigned to end users by their organization (work, school, non-profit) and managed by the admin. However, some business services like Yammer support work or school accounts that were created by end users, without IT involvement. We sometimes refer to these accounts as “viral” AAD accounts but we don’t use this term externally. Work or school accounts are stored in Azure Active Directory (AAD) and managed by Microsoft on behalf of the organization. One of the key difference with a Microsoft account is that users don’t own the account and will typically loose access to it if they leave the organization. Other aspects like password policies are imposed by admins.

A user account and associated credentials that is used to access Microsoft’s and 3rd parties’ business services, such as Office 365. Work or school accounts are usually assigned to end users by their organization (work, school, non-profit) and managed by the admin. However, some business services like Yammer support work or school accounts that were created by end users, without IT involvement. We sometimes refer to these accounts as “viral” AAD accounts but we don’t use this term externally. Work or school accounts are stored in Azure Active Directory (AAD) and managed by Microsoft on behalf of the organization. One of the key difference with a Microsoft account is that users don’t own the account and will typically loose access to it if they leave the organization. Other aspects like password policies are imposed by admins.
